characters: WILL YOU USE YOUR FREAKING TURN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun isn’t even up yet, but a sea of Amazonian red ros shine under the lights of the downtown flower mart. More than 80 VENDORS begin their day, readying their stal at the downtown flower mart where Angelenos come to buy t freshest, most extravagant flora in town. It's always springtime here. INT. REED BENNETT’S HOUSE - MID-WILSHIRE - 5 A.M. REED BENNETT (late 20s) wakes up easily, naturally. Handsome, rugged. Smile on his face, happy to be alive. H looks at the clock beside him. 5 a.m. Softly, he turns hi head. MORLEY CLARKSON (late 20s), lays sound asleep besid him. Reed gets up. Pulls on pajama bottoms. Then reaches under the bed, and pulls out a small box. Opens it. The perfect engagement ring inside. He sits on the bed, looking at her sleeping face. Softly pulls her left hand out from under the pillow. Reed now holds her naked left hand. When Morley wakes up. Catches the scene. She starts to say something, but:

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: I know you don’t like a big, mushy, romantic scene. No skywriting. No writing your name in flower petals. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: REED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just you and me. Together. And frankly, that’s all I want. That’s all I need. I love you Morley. Will you marry me? He looks at her, expectantly. And breathes a sigh of reli as she SMILES. EXT. REED BENNETT’S HOUSE - 5:40 A.M. Reed, now wearing a dark blue mechanics style jacket with words “Rita Flora” on the back, athletically barrels down stairs. Energy high. Excitement on his face. He gets inside a DELIVERY VAN.  2/18/9 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reed hops into the passenger side. ALPHONSO, 40s and from Salvador, is at the wheel. He looks at Reed, studying him

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: She said no. I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: I just mean -

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: She said yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: That’s great!

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Why would she say no?

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: I don’t know why I said that. I prepare for the worst. Part of the immigrant mentality. But - she said yes! Reed regains his enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: She said yes. She said YES. I’m still trying to process. Morley is actually going to marry me. I’m getting married. And today I can be the kind of cheeseball who tells random people at the ATM about it because it’s Valentine’s Day and people are all about love today. Alphonso pulls the VAN away, NEARLY HITTING A PASSING CAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alphonso turns to Reed, who smiles as they pull away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The set of the KTLA news is a flurry activity as the morn show is about to go on the air.  2/18/9 3. KELVIN, late 30s, African-American, walks briskly through set, holding a piece of paper. He spots SUSAN, 50s, across the stage, and makes a bee-li for her. As he approaches, he holds up the paper. He’s clearly annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: What the hell is this? Susan half-smiles, seeming to enjoy his frustration.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: That’s your assignment, Kelvin.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: My assignment? Since when do I get assignments?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Since there’s nothing else going on. Susan turns and walks through the stage, Kelvin follows.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: I’m the sports anchor, Susan. There’s always something going on.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: The Super Bowl was last week. There are only two NBA games tonight. No one gives a crap about hockey. Like I said, there’s nothing going on.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Actually I was working on something big - Susan stops, getting a little annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: What were you working on Kelvin? Was another one of the Cincinnati Bengals arrested? You got a tip on another referee fixing basketball games? Oooh - maybe you’ve got an exclusive one on one with Michael Vick’s dog trainer?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It’s Valentine’s Day. All I want is your basic man on the street remote about what this day means to people. I want happy. I want romance. I want love.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: And you should have that. But, seriously Susan - I’m not the right guy. I hate Valentine’s Day. Least favorite holiday. It’s not even a holiday, really, we don’t get the day off. So we have to go to work AND buy shit for people we might not even know in two weeks? No thanks. Susan laughs -

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Come on -

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: I’m serious. It’s the single man’s worst nightmare. I shut down dating from New Years Eve til Presidents Day just to avoid the whole thing. Saves me a lot of cash and heartache. Susan looks at him, almost sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Well, be that as it may - you’re a professional. I know you don’t like soccer but you give those Galaxy scores with a smile on your face. You'll do fine. She turns and leaves him standing there. EXT. FLOWER MART - DOWNTOWN L.A. - 6:00 A.M. Open for business and already crowded with wholesale BUYE readying for the busiest day of the year. Rows and rows of commercial floral delivery vans. Alphonso parks the van. Reed hops out. Behind him, two mo delivery vans bearing the RITA FLORA name park beside him Two LATINO DRIVERS stand outside, waiting for him.  2/18/9 5.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: You three pick up all the roses from Sam and load them in the trucks. I have to find something for Morley. Something spectacular. INT. AIRPLANE - 6:00 A.M. Jumbo jet. Long, overnight flight. All the passengers are asleep, fervently lost in their individual dreams. A FLIGHT ATTENDANT rubs her sleepy eyes. Gets up. She pins a heart on her lapel: Happy Valentine’s Day. Smacks it and it blinks red. She begins her hourly rounds Couple after couple asleep. Until she stops at one. A whi woman, KATE, (30s), in a military uniform, has fallen asl on the shoulder of HOLDEN, (30s) an African-American man. He leans into her, comforted by her warmth. The Flight Attendant pulls up the single blanket, wrappin them both tighter into a cocoon. EXT. FLOWER MART - VENDOR - 6:30 A.M. As Reed walks the aisles empty-handed, he’s jostled by al the other buyers, loaded down with fresh flowers. Unperturbed by the rudeness, Reed keeps smiling, wishing the Vendors, by name, a good morning. Finally, Reed finds a heavyset Italian ex-New Yorker with coffee spilled down his shirt, GUISEPPE (50s). Reed walks right behind the counter and smacks a kiss on Guiseppe’s cheek.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Guiseppe. I need you.

dialogues.speaker: GUISEPPE
dialogues.text: Great. But could you stand camera right? You're blocking my good angle. Guiseppe points to a three-man CAMERA CREW shooting close of all the flowers. KELVIN, now wearing a suit, on-air ma up, is quite debonair.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Morley said yes so I’m gonna need something --  2/18/9 6. Guiseppe looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: GUISEPPE
dialogues.text: She said yes?

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Yes. What is the deal with you guys? She wants to marry me - I swear. Guiseppe hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: GUISEPPE
dialogues.text: That’s great news.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: But I can’t just give her roses today. I need to find something amazing.

dialogues.speaker: GUISEPPE
dialogues.text: I think I have the perfect thing.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: GUISEPPE
dialogues.text: It’s in back.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BACK
dialogues.text: Guiseppe - followed by Reed - goes deep into the refrigerator. Pulls out something in a LONG, BLACK CLOSED BOX.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: What’s in it? He starts to open it. But Guiseppe stops him with a loud gruff.

dialogues.speaker: GUISEPPE
dialogues.text: No! Don’t open it until it’s just the right time.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: The right time?

dialogues.speaker: GUISEPPE
dialogues.text: Just trust me, Reed. I had this handpicked and flown over from Thailand, just in case you needed magic.  2/18/9

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: GUISEPPE
dialogues.text: Well, also, Damon Wayans shops here and I thought he might like it - but you got here first. Reed delicately takes the box.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Thank you, Guiseppe. You're the best.

dialogues.speaker: BACK OUT FRONT
dialogues.text: Reed, with the black box, and Guiseppe return. Kelvin approaches, smiles politely at Reed, then says to Guisepp

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Sir? If we can just get a few words from you on camera, then we'll be done. Kelvin turns to the camera crew. They start rolling.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: (into mic) We're here at the downtown Flower Mart in Los Angeles with wholesale dealer Guiseppe Carletti, where Valentine’s Day starts at three a.m. Guiseppe, on average, how Many red roses are sold on Valentine’s Day? Guiseppe is staring into the camera. Reed nudges him.

dialogues.speaker: GUISEPPE
dialogues.text: The Captain and Tennille were married on Valentine’s Day. Used to non-sequitur camera shock, Kelvin tries again.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Approximately 110 million red roses are sold in America on Valentine’s Day, am I right?

dialogues.speaker: GUISEPPE
dialogues.text: So were Meg Ryan and Dennis Quaid, but that didn’t end so well. Never understood why. She’s hot, that Meg Ryan. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUISEPPE (cont'd) I wouldn't mind delivering her flowers, if-you-know-what-I-mean. Guiseppe nods suggestively to camera. Reed steps in, protective.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: 110 million. That’s correct, Kelvin. And California produces about sixty percent of them.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: And your name, sir? Reed smiles easily into the camera.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Reed Bennett. Owner of Rita Flora on La Brea and Sixth.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Ah, as a florist, you must hear quite a few stories on Valentine’s Day. Do you believe in love?

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Hell, yes. Love is still the most shocking act left on the planet. Reed smiles. Electric. Kelvin knows a sound bite when he hears it. Smiles in the camera:

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Back to you, Cynthia. Signals the end. The camera turns off.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: GUISEPPE REED
dialogues.text: Of course. You're welcome. Follow Kelvin as he moves off with his crew:

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: That’s a start. Now, where else do they keep the deluded people? The guys walk off. Guiseppe and Reed watch them go. Guiseppe, baffled, turns Reed:  2/18/9 9.

dialogues.speaker: GUISEPPE
dialogues.text: Did I just tell the news that I wanted to give it to Meg Ryan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On JULIA PERSINGER (late 20s), beautiful, quirky, sitting in bed, smiling as she watches: DR. HARRISON COPELAND (40s, distinguished), a Reproductiv Endocrinologist (fertility expert) put on his tie. The TV SET is on in the background. Beat, as Harrison turns and takes her in. He clearly love her. She catches him looking at her, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Don’t leave today.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: I told you yesterday, I have to fly up to San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: But it’s Valentine’s Day.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: I know. And your face was the first thing I wanted to see this morning. But I have two in vitros at the clinic today. You can’t tell follicles when to burst. She moves around the condo now. Blacks and greys. Very male. As Julia reaches for her clothes, sexy red lingerie HARRISON (CONT’D) What about you? Are you really going to that dinner tonight?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. It technically is only for single people. But since you’re gonna be gone I’ve got nothing else to do. And it’s really important to Kara. It’sa tradition.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: You don’t really hate Valentine's Day, do you?  2/18/9 10. Julia is now a whirl, getting dressed. Shoes flying, skir pulled on. Tugging a brush through her hair. Trying to catch up and get ready to leave when he leaves.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: A recently divorced, handsome doctor such as yourself doesn’t know what it’s like to be single. But for us unhitched gals, well, it sucks. It’s like some sort of cosmic bitch-slap for singlefolk. The Universe saying, “Hey you! Remember what it felt like when you still had braces and cystic acne and no one wanted to ask you to winter formal? Well, nothing’s changed!” Harrison smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: I would take you to winter formal. And I definitely would have prescribed you some Retin A for the skin. She smiles back at him, but her attention is pulled to th screen.

dialogues.speaker: REED, (0.C., ON TV)
dialogues.text: ..-Love is still the most shocking act left on the planet. Julia smiles big.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: ...Thank you, Reed Bennett of Rita Flora.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I love that place. They have the most beautiful flowers. Harrison takes this in. Smiles at the joy on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE HIGH SCHOOL GIRLS, all wearing the standard Marlbor uniform, burst out of Starbucks on Larchmont, full of adolescent energy. They sip their chai lattes as they amb down the street.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH SCHOOL GIRL
dialogues.text: Flowers make me sad.  2/18/9 11.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH SCHOOL GIRL
dialogues.text: I know. They die.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH SCHOOL GIRL
dialogues.text: Right? What kind of gift is that?

dialogues.speaker: HIGH SCHOOL GIRL
dialogues.text: One that’s trying to send a message. Everything dies. Get used to it. As the girls continue to talk, we close in on JANICE (18) lags behind them, looking at her PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has ONE NEW TEXT. From someone named ALEX. It reads: “TODAY IS THE DAY!" She SMILES, somewhat shyly, as she reads this, then begin type her response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Loyola High School boys lacrosse practice is winding down. ALEX, 18, still in uniform, with helmet off, stands the sideline watching the second string run some drills. His PHONE, which sits in his helmet on the ground, BUZZES He picks it up, reads the return text from JANICE:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “YES! ye He smiles in anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 1940s four-plex on Spaulding. The typical just-moved-to L.A.-in-your-20s crash pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These apartments all have the same floor plan - all of th rooms off of a long, narrow hallway. In one of the bedroo we find JASON and LIZ (both mid 20s) curled up under a sh The decor says 25 year old messy guy.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Hello. Liz smiles shyly at him.  2/18/9 12.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I’m used to seeing you every morning -- but not exactly like this. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Would you prefer I were naked and wrapped in a sheet when you drop packages at my desk?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, I would. I don’t think that would be breaking any kind of office regulations. He puts his arms around her, and they start to kiss passionately.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: This, however, might start to draw attention... Jason laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: How is it possible that we didn’t start hanging out until three weeks ago?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Maybe you were scoping out some of the other assistants...

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. They kiss again. They are all smiles, as Liz glances at t clock.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: So, I guess I better get going soon...

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Uh, OK. Great. She hesitates for a moment, waiting for something.  2/18/9 13.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well... OK... I guess I’1l just see you there... She hesitates again, looking at Jason. He looks back at h Again - she’s waiting for something. He’s clearly not sur what. And whatever it is doesn’t come. She finally gets u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz drives a little Hyundai - pulls up to a stoplight on Beverly Blvd. Liz looks out the window - and sees Jason, on his Vespa, waving to her. She gives him a thin lipped smile. He motions for her to roll down her window. She does.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Hi. Jason smiles again at Liz. She forces a smile back. It’s awkward as they wait for the light. It FINALLY turns gree

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Bye! They mercifully pull away. EXT. EDGAR & ESTELLE’S HOUSE - BACK YARD - MORNING French doors open into the backyard. ESTELLE (70s), her flaxen white hair, pale skin and full lips telling the st of a once great beauty, is still sleeping in the bed. EDGAR (70s), a tall old-fashioned gentleman in a sweater arm patches, walks slowly through the overgrown English garden, cutting flowers with a pair of garden shears. INT. EDGAR & ESTELLE’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - MORNING Edgar places the flowers, now in a drinking glass, with a of Chanel No. 5 perfume on the nightstand beside his slee wife. He kisses her on the forehead, waking her gently. She sti smiles at the man she’s been married to for 51 years. See the flowers and perfume.  2/18/9 14.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: Edgar, we said we weren't going to celebrate Valentine’s Day anymore.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: I lied. Estelle reaches under her pillow. Pulls out a brand new pipe, wrapped in a red ribbon. Hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: So did I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDISON (10) sits at the kitchen table. A multi-pack of ki mini-boxes of cereal sits in front of him next to an empt cereal bowl. The kitchen TV is on in the background. Edison takes his eyes off the TV and looks down at the store-bought box of VALENTINES laid out in front of him. He finds the biggest He signs it, “I love you. Edison.” On the outside, he dra a simple heart and sets it apart from the others.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN THE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Edgar and Estelle walk, both dressed now. She in her lipstick. He with slicked hair. Both adhering to the old ways of being “dressed” for the breakfast table. She lean into him. He links her arm into his. They stop in the doorway, watching Edison write out his Valentines. A sadness passes over Estelle.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: The boy misses his mother. Every year, she was his Valentine. Edgar looks at her, sympathetic.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: We're doing the best we can. Together, they enter the kitchen. Loving smiles now.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Where Edison refers to his class list and starts addressi the rest when Edgar and Estelle walk in. They both kiss their grandson, when Estelle notices the empty cereal bow  2/18/9 15.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: What about your breakfast, Edison?

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Not hungry. I’m in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Running down the beach fluidly is SEAN JACKSON, 35, clear an athlete who’s stride leaves not an ounce of wasted mot He approaches a massive HOUSE right on the beach, runs up deck stairs and into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean, just out of the shower, enters the impressive bathr in a towel. He grabs his toothbrush, begins to brush his teeth. Looks to his right at the other sink of the two si vanity. It’s devoid of any personal items except for ONE TOOTHBRUSH sitting in a cup. Sean stares at it. Finally he grabs the lone toothbrush a tosses it into the trash can at his feet. Continues brush his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean, now dressed, enters from the kitchen holding a prot type shake. The TV is tuned to ESPN - the morning edition Sportscenter. ON THE TV - The ANCHOR sits at the familiar Sportscenter desk, with a graphic of SEAN OVER HIS RIGHT SHOULDER.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR
dialogues.text: With the NFL season officially over, the only lingering question is - what will Sean Jackson do? IN THE HOUSE - This clearly gets Sean’s attention. He sit on his couch, watches. ON THE TV - The anchor continues: ANCHOR (CONT’D) A devastating loss in the Super Bowl last week leaves his future with the Chargers in question. Over FOOTAGE OF SEAN, AT QB, VARIOUS HIGHLIGHT PLAYS.  2/18/9 16. ANCHOR (V.O.) (CONT’D) His contract is up, and at 35, he’s not getting any younger. Do the Chargers want him back? If not, will he test the waters of free agency? Or will he make this easier on everyone and just retire? IN THE HOUSE - As Sean watches, that last line hits him h

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We expect an answer to all these questions and more over the next few days... Sean flips the TV off, not happy. He picks up the PHONE, dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spare modern home up Outpost. From overhead we find KAR 37, sleeping alone in perhaps the largest bed available f purchase. She looks like a 2 year old on a normal size be The PHONE RINGS, startling her awake. She crawls across t bed to her nightstand and hits the SPEAKER BUTTON ON HER PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (ON SPEAKER)
dialogues.text: Kara - it’s Sean.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Hey. What’s going on? Kara sits up. She leans over and grabs her LAPTOP from th nightstand, opens it up.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MALIBU BEACH HOUSE
dialogues.text: Sean now stands on his deck overlooking the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Can’t you stop these assholes on ESPN from talking shit about me?

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Um, no, not really. I'ma publicist Sean, not a dictator. Sean’s pacing his deck, thinking. Kara types away on her laptop.  2/18/9 17.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: OK. Then I need to make a decision. I can’t take this anymore. Are you free today?

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Yeah, pretty much. Kara keeps typing, half-engaged in the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I can hear you typing. Are you checking your email while we're talking?

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: No. I’m checking my Evite. Sean actually cracks a smile.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Oh right. Your “I Hate Valentine’s Day Dinner”. You still do that?

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: It’s a tradition. Me and all my friends get together and share our mutual disdain for the holiday. It’s fun.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: It sounds fun.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: No it doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: It sounds like a nightmare. Kara laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Expecting a big turnout?

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: I‘11 tell you in a second. Kara punches in the Evite address. The site comes up. ON THE SCREEN - We see Kara’s nicely designed Evite - the title “I HATE VALENTINE’S DAY DINNER” scrolling across th top.  2/18/9 18. We move to the NUMBER OF ATTENDEES LINE. The number following it - 0. WITH KARA - As she squints her eyes, not sure she’s readi it right. She stares in shocked silence.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: I gotta call you back. Kara, slams her computer shut, hits the speaker button on nightstand again, hops out of bed quickly. She grabs her CELL PHONE out of her purse, dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: La Brea Avenue. Reed has turned a typical floral shop int hip coffee spot, selling muffins and coffee to go. Fresh flowers on every bistro table. The place is PACKED. Long lines of CUSTOMERS buying flowers from an already ti STAFF. Reed is deftly managing the lines at the very busy coffee counter. He hands coffee and muffins to A COUPLE.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Here you go. I gave you two banana nut for the price of one -- little engagement special. They couple SMILES as they take their goods.

dialogues.speaker: REED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who’s up next? In honor of Valentine’s day - and my engagement - a good proposal story means a free specialty drink. He is obviously skilled at entertaining the crowd. As he goes to steam another latte - MORLEY walks in. As soon as the staff-members see her -- they BURST INTO APPLAUSE. Re turns to see her and joins in the cheering.

dialogues.speaker: REED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The future Mrs. Bennett, ladies and gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MEMBER
dialogues.text: We're so happy for you two!! As they clap and congratulate her, she smiles very uncomfortably.  2/18/9 She looks He kisses 19.

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY
dialogues.text: I wasn’t really expecting this... pleadingly at Reed.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Morley really does not like people making a fuss over her - her -

dialogues.speaker: REED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I just thought we'd carry her on our shoulders around the store like one time - two times tops - They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: REED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm kidding. (handing his apron to a clerk) Can you take over for me for a minute? He ushers Morley into the back.

dialogues.speaker: REED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nice to see you. Fiance. That word is weird, right? Have you said it yet?

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: So, did you just come by to bask in the glow of our fiance-ness? Try saying it once-- She reaches into her purse -

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY
dialogues.text: You actually just left your cell phone charging on the kitchen counter - so I thought I’d drop it off. She goes to hand him the phone with her LEFT HAND.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: That was sweet. Thanks.  2/18/9 20.

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY
dialogues.text: Of course. I know you need it when you're making deliveries. Redd looks at her hand. NO RING. She looks up - sees the hurt in this face.

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t be upset. It’s a beautiful ring. Beautiful. It’s just - so big. And sparkly.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: That’s bad?

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY
dialogues.text: It’s just - a lot. I mean for work and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY
dialogues.text: You know how women get - they see the ring - and then next thing you know you’re giving the whole engagement story to a complete stranger. Who wants that? Morley looks up at Reed - who is suppressing a smile.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: I don’t know - that sounds kind of nice. Maybe I should wear the ring? She LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY
dialogues.text: I’ve always wondered why men don’t have to wear engagement rings. They’re engaged, too.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Good point. I feel slighted.

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY
dialogues.text: You are welcome to try mine. If you can pull of an emerald cut diamond with pave band - you are more of a man than I even thought. He laughs, and kisses her.  2/18/9 21.

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, I should let you get back to the masses out there. Morley turns to go, and is wrapped into a BEAR HUG by Alphonso.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY
dialogues.text: Thank you. He kisses her on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh. Thanks. And on the other cheek.

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. I should probably get going.

dialogues.speaker: ALOOFNESS
dialogues.text: I am so happy for you guys. She smiles as he pulls away. Reed laughs.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: See you at home. Fiance. She takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kate wakes up, startled to find herself wrapped in someon else’s arms. She jerks up, immediately alert and containe

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir. Holden’s awake, and has been for over an hour.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: It’s just a shoulder. Ona fourteen-hour flight, it’s the least I could do.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You should have moved me. I apologize for the inconvenience. Kate adjusts her uniform, puts herself back together.  2/18/9 22.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: Are you on active duty?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: Loved one in Los Angeles? Kate doesn’t answer. Doesn’t like the personal questions.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: I’m sure he’1ll be happy to see you.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I hope so. I’ve been on duty for two years now. Holden smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: Will you be staying long?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I only have 24 hours leave in Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: Ah, so you’re a romantic.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: Fourteen hours to and from Iraq for one night with your husband? I'd call that romantic. She doesn’t know how to take that. So she says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A two-bedroom Art Deco apartment on Sycamore, one block f La Brea. Warm, inviting. Julia, just out of the shower, walks through her living r in a towel. She grabs her phone, sees she has a message. She puts it on speaker:

dialogues.speaker: KARA, (ON SPEAKER)
dialogues.text: Hey, Julia, it’s Kara. So, I’m freaking out a bit. I’m really hoping you're coming to my dinner tonight. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KARA (ON SPEAKER) (cont'd) It’s turning out to be a little - smaller - than I had hoped. OK. Call me. Julia deletes the message. She thinks about it, picks up phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: (into phone) Harrison? Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From inside his convertible Porsche, Harrison answers.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: (into phone) I can’t talk now, honey. I’m about to pull into LAX. I’11 call you when I land. He hangs up. Then pulls up to the MALIBU COLONY GATES. Hi face pained at the lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harrison walks in, carrying his daughter OLIVIA (10) on h shoulders, to find ALEXANDRA (40s), pouring orange juice.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Daddy was up all night delivering TWINS! Two babies from the same mommy . He puts Olivia down, walks over to his wife. Kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: Sorry it took so long. We didn’t deliver until almost four, so I slept at the condo. She smiles, used to it.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDRA
dialogues.text: How'd the delivery go?

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: Good. All things considered. Olivia picks up a LARGE VALENTINE. Hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: This is for you.  2/18/9 24. He opens it. The childish pencil writing of, “I love you. Olivia.” He looks at her, looks at his wife. Then suddenl breaks. A few tears. No warning. Then he shrugs it off.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Don’t you like it, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: Of course I do. Daddy’s just tired, that’s all. He walks over to Alexandra. Kisses her deeply.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDRA
dialogues.text: What was that for?

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: Nothing. I’11l see you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelvin and his crew shoot close on a tattoo on a burly ar Half a woman’s name -- ELIZAB -- still shows. As the TATT ARTIST is completing the “eth” he says:

dialogues.speaker: TATTOO ARTIST
dialogues.text: (as he works) All day. Names on shoulders, hearts on ass cracks.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: So it’s busy?

dialogues.speaker: TATTOO ARTIST
dialogues.text: Busiest day of the year. And it’s the gift that keeps on giving.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: TATTOO ARTIST
dialogues.text: Because I take off more names than I put on. You know why? Because--- He stops his work, points to tattoo on his arm: LOVE IS PISS.

dialogues.speaker: TATTOO ARTIST
dialogues.text: That used to say Lucille. Kelvin looks at his CREW. Makes the “cut” sign.  2/18/9 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia enters Rita Flora, smiles when she sees Reed behind counter. She sidles up to him.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I saw you on TV this morning. “Love is the most shocking act left on the planet.” That should be on a bumper sticker. But she smiles, teasing. He goes to the espresso machine, starts making Julia’s coffee himself. He hands her the coffee. Refuses her money.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Happy Valentine’s Day.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Thank you - but don’t try to deflect. How did it go? Reed peeks up at the line - growing longer by the second. But can’t resist Julia’s expectant face. He turns to a

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Henry, you got this? HENRY nods. Reed steps aside, to talk to Julia more privately. Before he can start, she looks at his face.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Oh, shit... Reed looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Does anyone have any confidence in me? She said yes. Julia smiles big and HUGS him.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Yay! That’s amazing. How much did she love that ring? He hedges. Not wanting to disappoint her.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: She thought it was a beautiful ring, just not the right ring. Julia bites her lip, instantly sensitive for him.  2/18/9

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: It just wasn’t her speed. It’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I guess. But I feel like if Harrison and I ever got engaged or anything, I’d be happy with a cigar band. Reed looks a little taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Wow. Things are going well with him, then?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Yeah. He had to go to San Francisco today. I was thinking of surprising him. You know, fly up there and rock his world on the Golden Gate Bridge. Too much?

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Really? So if a girl did that for you, you wouldn’t be freaked out?

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: No. I love spontaneity. Julia considers this, then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: That’s true. I remember in college you made me drive around all night with you looking for the perfect donut. That was spontaneous.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: And sickening. Humans are not meant to ingest that much fried dough.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: No they’re not. Reed smiles. ALPHONSO interrupts them.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: No mas raffia, boss.  2/18/9 27.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Take the flight, Julia. Valentine’s Day is like New Year's Eve. You don’t think, you just go for it. He smiles, and leaves her thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the bowels of the agency, Jason, and his buddy, DANNY, sort a gargantuan pile of mail. These aren't just any mailroom guys - these guys are good looking, dressed well, agents in the making.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She wouldn’t even give you a ride in to work?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: No, she would. She just thinks it’s better to keep it discreet, you know?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: So why are you telling me? He has a good point, but before Jason can respond, JED, a third mailroom guy enters, carrying TWO GIANT FLOWER ARRANGEMENTS.

dialogues.speaker: JED
dialogues.text: Dude, I hate Valentine’s Day. Why can’t these pansy guys just go upstairs and deliver their flowers to their girlfriends themselves? Jason looks confused - and a little horrified.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Wait - what?

dialogues.speaker: JED
dialogues.text: These guys just drop the stuff of at the curb - they don’t want to take the time to -

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: No - wait - it’s Valentine’s Day? But it’s Monday. I thought it was always on a Thursday.  2/18/9 28.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Dude, that’s Thanksgiving.

dialogues.speaker: JED
dialogues.text: You're 25. You’ve thought that for 25 years? That’s really weird. Jason looks a little panicked.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Shit. I didn’t even say Happy Valentine’s Day. Danny and Jed start to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: And you have nothing planned?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: No. But we’ve only been together a couple of weeks. Maybe she doesn’t expect anything. Jed and Danny share a look.

dialogues.speaker: JED
dialogues.text: You're screwed. Off Jason, not liking the sound of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz sits at her tiny, neat assistant’s desk. She taps awa at her computer when ERIN, her boss, approaches. Liz tens

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Can I see the phone sheet? Liz hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I still haven't heard back from Dominic about the conference call.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: I talked to him. He’s in London. He wants to do the call tomorrow morning. Erin starts to walk into her office.

dialogues.speaker: ERIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s tomorrow morning London time. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ERIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, I need you to be here tonight to patch it through. As long as you're here by about 10 tonight it should be fine. Erin waits by the door to her office, waiting for an answ

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Tonight?

dialogues.speaker: ERIN
dialogues.text: Yeah. We’ve been trying to make this happen for weeks, so we really can’t wait any longer. You don’t have plans tonight, do you? Liz hesitates momentarily, and then smiles at her boss - picture of efficiency.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: No. No plans. I1’11 be here. Erin nods, and heads back into her office. The phone ring Liz dutifully picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar drives his grandson Edison to school. Edison holds Valentines firmly in his lap. The biggest one -- with the single red heart on the envelope -- is on top.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: (beat) Tell me the story about the postbox.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: (smiling) I’ve told you that before.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: I know. It just makes more sense now that I’m in love.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: I was nineteen. Your grandma was eighteen. I was an architect. I worked in the front office with a big window. Your grandma would come out every morning and post the mail. Then she’d sneak a smoke. Edison puts his hand over his heart.  2/18/9 30.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Smoking is bad, I know. I solemnly swear never to smoke. Go on. Edgar can’t help but smile.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: I thought she was the prettiest girl I’d ever seen, so I got up my courage and waited by the postbox to say hello.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Only you didn’t say a word because you were afraid.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: That’s right. So she pushed me aside, and said, “Move, big fella.”

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: But you kept coming back every day until she agreed to go out with you. Edison looks at him, very seriously. Digesting it all. Ed pulls the car over in front of Rita Flora.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: You don’t have to come in. I can do this myself. He’s out of the car, heavy backpack bobbing behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edison, a long line behind him, finally reaches Reed at t counter.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: I want to send a dozen red roses to the best girl at my school. Edison drops a stack of wrinkled dollar bills on the coun Reed picks up the money. Counts it.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Thirteen dollars.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: You can have all of it. Crescent Elementary. You can MapQuest it. He hands him the Valentine with the heart on the envelope  2/18/9 31.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: 5th period - like between 1 and 2pm - would be ideal. Just hand me the flowers when you get there. I’11 take care of the rest. Reed takes the Valentine. Looks at Edison’s very serious, very in love face. Makes a decision.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: You got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janice sits in a classroom with about 10 other girls, all focused on the teacher, MS. GILROY (27, fragile), who is wrapping up class.

dialogues.speaker: MS. GILROY
dialogues.text: Remember girls, registration for the AP exam must be in by next week, so don’t flake. Promise me. This class is way too hard to take just for fun. The BELL RINGS and the girls swiftly pack up their things begin to head out. Ms. Gilroy stops Janice as she leaves. MS. GILROY (CONT’D) That last comment wasn’t directed at you. I just realized it could have sounded that way.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: That’s fine. I didn’t take it that way.

dialogues.speaker: MS. GILROY
dialogues.text: OK. Even though, since you’ve already taken the AP test, you are kind of taking this class for fun.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: I take all my classes for fun Ms. Gilroy. Ms. Gilroy doesn’t know how to deal with this weird alien child.  2/18/9

dialogues.speaker: MS. GILROY
dialogues.text: Right. Anyway, I’m putting together a little study group for the girls and I was wondering if I could pick your brain at some point about what I should focus on. You know, since you’ve recently taken the test. And I - never did.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Sure - of course.

dialogues.speaker: MS. GILROY
dialogues.text: Great. How about today after school?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Oh, I can’t. I nanny after school.

dialogues.speaker: MS. GILROY
dialogues.text: OK. Tomorrow morning?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: I teach yoga before school on Wednesdays and Fridays. You should come. I think it would be helpful. Ms. Gilroy isn’t sure how to take that.

dialogues.speaker: MS. GILROY
dialogues.text: I‘1l consider that. I’m guessing evenings are out of the question?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I take a few classes at UCLA.

dialogues.speaker: MS. GILROY
dialogues.text: Alright then. Wow you’re busy. How about today at lunch? Janice smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Normally that would work - but today I’m going to have sex with my boyfriend for the first time - or, I mean, to be accurate, I’m going to have sex for the first time, he will be too, so - Ms. Gilroy’s face freezes.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s Valentine’s Day. And my parents work during the day. So it’s really the only time it can happen. Ms. Gilroy is now speechless. She begins shuffling papers her desk.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But tomorrow at lunch I’m free.

dialogues.speaker: MS. GILROY
dialogues.text: (wanting this to end) Great!

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Great. I’1l see you then. So excited. Janice hustles out, leaving Ms. Gilroy dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean walks into the CAA building, heads for the RECEPTION

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Sean Jackson here for Drew Goss. The receptionist nods, dials a few numbers. As Sean waits, JASON comes walking by, wheeling his cart packages and mail. He drops some mail off at the front de He nods at Sean (who he clearly recognizes), Sean nods ba As he passes, Jason breaks out in a big smile.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: (to Sean) They'll be right down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean and Kara sit across from DREW, Sean’s 28 year old superagent.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: So the Chargers have - passed.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: They've decided not to pursue resigning you.  2/18/9 34.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: I’m working on a press release saying it was a mutual parting. Sean looks at them both, head spinning.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: OK. But - why? We got to the Super Bowl. I was second team All- Pro -

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: They wanna go in a different direction. They’ve got their sights set on that kid from Alabama- Sean rubs his head, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Whatever - I don’t...So - now what?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Now what? It’s simple. Now we pick a different team. I’ve gotten calls from the Bills, the Vikings - Sean begins shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Uh-uh. You're telling me I’ve got to move? To Buffalo? Are you insane? Me in Buffalo?

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: OK - then we’ll pursue some other teams -

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: It’s not that man, it’s just - I don’t know. Maybe I’m done.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: Absolutely not. And I’m not saying this as an agent who makes money off of you. I’m saying this as a fan - you can still play. Sean cracks a smile.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I know I can. I know. But - He turns to Kara.  2/18/9

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Kara, you get it, right?

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Drew - I know you’ve only been my agent for a few years, so you might not know - but this job has cost me a lot. Relationships. I wanted to be a father, man. But -

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: You can still do all that stuff and play football Sean.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Not in this league you can’t. Not if you want to do it right. It’s too hard. Trust me. Sean looks at them both.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need to think about this. Sean gets up, heads out the door.
Reed and Alphonso are packing a delivery van with orders.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Do you think it should bum me out she’s not wearing the ring? I tried to go with simple and classic, but I don’t think I nailed it. It’s weird - I feel like I’m always really trying to get it right with her - and I always miss the mark a little.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: No, I don’t think it should bum you out.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: I think it should bum you out when you stop trying.  2/18/9 36. They walk back into the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Reed sees another long line. Harried staff taking orders. He walks up behind the counter. Grabs another ord slip.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Next? It’s Harrison. Only he’s walked around the line to the front.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: May I speak to the manager?

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: I’m the owner.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: Perfect. I hate to pull this card - but I’m a doctor and I need to get back to the hospital - and I wanted to take care of this order myself.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: No problem. Come over here and I‘’1l write you up. Reed walks him over to a side table.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: I need you to deliver two arrangements for me. Two dozen red roses for each -- lady. And I need your discretion. Do you understand? This isn’t the first time Reed’s gotten an order like thi

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: I appreciate that. Harrison hands him two slips of paper.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: Here are the addresses.  2/18/9 37. Reed starts writing up the order. Then freezes.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Let me see if I am understanding this correctly. This first order is for Alexandra Copeland in Malibu. That’s your wife?

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: And this second order is for Julia Persinger at Crescent Elementary school? Now, is Julia your daughter? Harrison is uncomfortable. Not a complete jerk.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: No. Now, look. I thought we had an understanding.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: We do. I just wanted to make sure we're understanding the same understanding.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: We are. He hands Reed a credit card. Reed takes it. Slides it through the machine. Doing his best to conceal his anger. INT. CRESCENT ELEMENTARY - JULIA’S CLASSROOM - MORNING The room is full of 10 YEAR OLDS. Edison amongst them. There are several girls behind him, most notably MADISON, very pretty blonde girl. Edison pays close attention to Julia, at the head of the class.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Okay. Now we’re going to put all our Valentines into the envelopes we made yesterday. She points to one wall, full of colored construction pape envelopes with names on them.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: But before we do that, a little history. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JULIA (cont'd) Back in Ancient Rome, Claudius the Cruel banned all marriages because he only wanted his soldiers to believe in war. But a priest named Valentine secretly married everyone anyway because he believed in love. But when Claudius the Cruel found out, he arrested Valentine and threw him into prison. Then, on February 14th, the day Valentine was to be execu -- Julia stops, looks at the young faces. Thinks better of i

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: -- Well, on February 14th, Valentine sent a letter to his true love and signed it, “Farewell. From your Valentine.” Edison throws up his hand.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: You were going to say executed! Executed equals killed! They killed Valentine because he married people in love?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: It seems so, Edison. But isn’t it nice that every year people who believe in love, like he did, send Valentines in his honor? Edison nods in agreement. Meanwhile, Madison turns to GWE sitting behind her.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: Did you bring the extras like I told you?

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: Yes. Madison picks through them, taking an especially gooey on She signs it: I love you, From Edison.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: I thought you liked Edison? You put his initials on the bottom of your shoe. Madison looks at Edison’s back. His head bent over gently Her eyes narrow. Clearly, he’s done her wrong.  2/18/9 39.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: He didn’t like me back. I hate him. Madison looks around the class. Lands on RANI, a shy Indi girl.

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Perfect. She writes “Rani” on the envelope and slips the “I love y Edison” Valentine inside.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Okay. Start delivering your Valentines. We’1ll open them after lunch. The class gets up. As Julia watches, the children drop Valentines into the brightly colored envelopes on the wal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CITY BUS pulls up to the corner and Alex hops out in hi Loyola school uniform. He holds a rather large duffel bag He checks his phone, which has a new text message from Janice. It reads: ALMOST THERE! Alex quickly takes off down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex walks up the front lawn of a well-kept 1910 Craftsma He squats down in front of a LARGE POTTED PLANT on the po and fishes out the SPARE KEY. He unlocks the door, replaces the key, and enters the hou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex makes his way to Janice’s bedroom and starts unpacki his bag. He pulls out a bunch of CANDLES, quickly setting them up around the bed. He pulls out a newly bought CANDLE WAND a hastily opens it, lighting all the candles as fast as he He takes out a box of CONDOMS and puts them on the nightstand. Then he undoes his tie, unbuttons his shirt and strips do to his boxers. He hops on the bed, trying to position himself suggestively for Janice’s entrance.  2/18/9 40. He finds that he’s staring at himself in the MIRRORED CLO across the room. And he looks really lame. He tries anoth pose - on his side, propped up by his elbow - way too Playgirl. He tries sitting cross-legged - now it looks li he’s meditating amongst all the candles. Finally he gets up and throws a sheet over the mirror. As he’s trying to get it to stay up, he hears the FRONT DOOR OPEN. He scrambles back to the bed and lies down. He tries to contain his excitement as he hears footsteps down the hall. Then, as the footsteps get to the bedroom door he sees not Janice but her mom GRACE (40, pretty) walking past the open door. Alex panics and slides off the bed, knocking over a candl

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Shit! Grace runs to the doorway, shocked to see Alex, in his boxers, trying to get up.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: Alex?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Mrs. Smart I’m so sorry. Alex quickly tries to blow out all the candles and gather clothes. It’s not going well.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I - uhh - I - was trying to take a nap.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: With all these candles?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: It relaxes me. Grace looks at Alex, now with all his clothes in his arms bag over his shoulder, still only in his boxers.

dialogues.speaker: GRACE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry to interrupt you then. Go back to sleep.  2/18/9

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No, it’s fine. anyway. Alex hurriedly tries to push squeezing through the door. footing and FALLS FACE FIRST 41. I need to go past Grace into the hallway, But in doing so he loses his in the hall, bag and clothes flying everywhere. to his feet, but as he does his on the baseboard, RIPPING HIS feet. He quickly tries to scramble boxers CATCH ON THE DOORSTOP BOXERS OFF as he hops to his Grace tries to avert her eyes at the sight of Alex’s bare ass, and he quickly grabs his clothes and bag and scurrie outside, completely naked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janice pulls up in her beat up Camry and parks in front o her house. She checks herself in her rearview mirror, putting on a little lip-gloss, fluffing her hair. Then, behind her in the mirror she notices ALEX RUNNING D THE SIDEWALK, NAKED, covered by the bundle of clothes in front of him. Her eyes open wide. He reaches her car and hops in - out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Mom.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Your mom?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yeah. My mom was at your house.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Oh. (she looks at his nakedness ) Shit! My mom! What’d you say?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: That I was taking a nap.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No - the naked part came after I told her that.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Wait - what?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Seriously, there’s no explaining this. Just drive. She could be coming out any second. Janice starts the car and pulls out. INT. JANICE’S CAR - DAY Janice and Alex sit in her parked car outside of Loyola H School, Alex now fully dressed.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What about after school?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Come on Alex, you know I nanny.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Right. Can you skip your class tonight?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Skip class? Do you know me at all?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Sorry. And I work tonight until 11. Crap. They both sit there in silence, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, maybe we’re just putting too much pressure on it being today. The whole point initially was to do it before we went off to college - and we still have 6 months before that.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: I’m thinking about going to the summer program at Yale - you know, to get a head start. That’s June.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: OK, so 4 months. That’s stilla long time.  2/18/9 43. Janice doesn’t like the sound of that.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: No, no, no. It’s gotta be today. When someone asks me when I first had sex, I don’t wanna say “Oh, I don’t quite remember, some random day between February and June of my senior year.” It’s gotta be special Alex. And today is special. Alex looks at Janice, sees how serious she is about this.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: OK. Just - give me some time. I‘1l figure this out. I promise. Janice looks at him, softening. She nods. He leans in and gives her a kiss, then hops out of the car and heads towa school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz sits at her desk, typing wildly fast. Jason approache wheeling a cart with packages. He approaches Liz with som trepidation.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Hey. She looks up.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Oh. Hey. She goes right back to work. Hardly a warm greeting.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Didn't I see that shirt yesterday? He’s trying to make a joke. She doesn’t laugh. He’s clear gotta try harder.

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, I didn’t know that today was Valentine’s Day. I thought it was the second Thursday -- Her look says she’s not buying it.

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I swear. I know it sounds stupid - but I always do stupid stuff. Ask my mom —- He picks up her phone -

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here. You wanna call her? Maybe she'll tell you about the time I got trapped in a volleyball net -- She cracks a smile. He’s clearly trying.

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Happy Valentine’s day. She softens.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: So, can I take you out tonight?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Well, I kind of already said I'd -

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I will hook up something great - She considers this.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Yeah, OK. That sounds good.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Cool. He turns to go, with his cart.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: You’re not gonna deliver those?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: These are actually decoys. I just wanted to have a reason to come talk to you. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Really well engineered plan. I totally fell for it.  2/18/9 45. He smiles as he heads back to the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LARGE INFLATABLE RAT is parked in front of a PEP BOYS, stopping traffic. Kelvin and the camera crew interview a petite round CHOLA (18). Eyebrows single slashes of orange liquid liner.

dialogues.speaker: CHOLA
dialogues.text: I was hot like jalapena, sexing him up whenever he wanted. I would have done anything for that vato, but still he whored around. She points to the rat. A sign around its neck: CISCO MARTINEZ IS A CHOLO RAT WHORE.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: (points to the rat) Has he seen it? She looks back at the open bay of the Pep Boys, where all employees are laughing and pointing, except one: CISCO (n embroidered on his work shirt) who pretends not to notice he angrily works on a Buick, cranked up on hydraulics. Chola smiles. Extremely pleased.

dialogues.speaker: CHOLA
dialogues.text: No. I don’t think he has. Knowing full well, he has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kara slowly makes her way around the store, an explosion Valentine’s Day decorations. She halfheartedly fills her cart with red streamers, hanging hearts, etc. She starts to make her way to the back, but the aisle is blocked by the cart of a YOUNG COUPLE who are goofing aro trying different Valentine’s Day hats and glasses on each other. Kara waits patiently for them to notice her, but it’s not happening. Then they start MAKING OUT as Kara spectates. She can’t believe this. It’s like the longest kiss on record. Finally, Kara’s had enough. She takes her cart and RAMS I INTO THEIRS, WHICH IN TURN RAMS INTO THEM, breaking their embrace. Kara gives them a small smile as she passes.  2/18/9 46.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Sorry. As Kara turns down the next aisle, her PHONE RINGS. She picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: KARA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hey Jan.

dialogues.speaker: JAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’ve got Kelvin Briggs for you.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: From KTLA? Tell him I’11 call him back.

dialogues.speaker: JAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He’s called 15 times already.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Fine. Put him on. Kara throws a few balloons in her cart.

dialogues.speaker: JAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Kara, you’re on with Kelvin.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Hey Kelvin. What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SUNSET BLVD.
dialogues.text: Kelvin stands a few feet away from his crew, on the phone The HUGE RAT is in the background.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Well, the press release just came off the wire...

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: And...

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: And I know that Sean’s not gonna want this to drag on for too long. He’s gonna make a decision soon. So here’s what I’m thinking. When he does decide - whatever he decides, whether to play for another team or god forbid retire - I think you should give the exclusive to me. Local player gives big story to local sports guy. It’s a win-win.  2/18/9 47. Kara smiles at his forwardness.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Yeah, but both wins are for you.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Well, not necessarily -

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Look Kelvin, I don’t know what to tell you. I’m sure this is just gonna be your usual, run of the mill press conference. I don’t think there’s any exclusive to be had here. But I appreciate the ambition. Happy Valentine’s Day. Kelvin grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Yeah right. I can’t wait for this day to be over. Kara smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: You and me both. Bye Kelvin. She hangs up. Kara makes her way to the register, starts unloading her stuff. As the cashier starts to ring it up-

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Wow. Someone’s having a big -

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Seriously, don’t. The cashier goes back to his job, chastened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean drives down Little Santa Monica, classical music BLARING. He’s lost in thought. Oblivious, he turns LEFT too quickly -- REAR ENDING A RIT FLORA VAN. He gets out and approaches the van - as ALPHONSO gets out the driver side, not happy. Sean is instantly apologetic.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry man.  2/18/9 48.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: You should pay more attention, guy.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I know. I don’t know what’s wrong with me today. Sean pulls out his wallet, hands Alphonso a card.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just call my business manager - he’s got all my info. Alphonso takes the card.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: Must be nice. Alphonso turns to check out the damage to the back of the - in the collision the back doors have popped open. Sean notices the back FILLED WITH FLOWERS.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Man. That many people get flowers delivered?

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: It’s Valentine’s Day. Kind of a big day, flower-wise.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: No - I know. I just mean - why would you get flowers delivered when you could just go buy them and give them at home? It seems more personal that way. Alphonso’s having a tough time with the damaged doors.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: People like to get flowers at their place of work. They like a public declaration. It’s like - love doesn’t exist until you acknowledge it in front of people. Sean TAKES THIS IN. Alphonso finally gets the doors to st shut, heads back to the driver’s side. ALPHONSO (CONT’D) Keep your eyes open friend. He shuts the driver side door. Sean stands there and watc Alphonso pull away - a SMILE GROWING ON HIS FACE.  2/18/9 49. He whips out his cell phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hey Kara, it’s Sean. I made my decision. Sean hops in his car, takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alphonso drives down little Santa Monica. He checks his rearview mirror - sees:

dialogues.speaker: THE DOORS OPEN AGAIN.
dialogues.text: SEVERAL flower arrangements fall out, hitting the ground kaleidoscope of glass and color. Cards hitting the paveme We narrow in on one card: EDISON’S ENVELOPE with the simp red heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alphonso pulls over quickly. Picks up his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quickly, Reed and Alphonso are transferring all the flora arrangements from Alphonso’s bum van to Reed’s van. Reed upset, thrown off his game.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous. There’s easily several hundred dollars worth of damage here. We're already behind on our delivery schedule. And then I find out that Julia’s boyfriend is married. I mean, what am I supposed to do with that? I shouldn't tell her, right? Who wants to hear that? (he looks at Alphonso, hopeful) I should probably just stay out of it, right? Alphonso grimaces. Thinks. Says:

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: I think you have to tell her. Reed deflates.  2/18/9 50.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Really? Why?

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: Because it’s the right thing to do. INT. CRESCENT ELEMENTARY - JULIA’S CLASSROOM - DAY The kids all file back into class after lunch. Edison wal up the aisle and passes Rani, who sits at her desk, liste to her iPod. As he passes -

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Whatcha listening to Rani? Rani pulls out one earbud, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RANI
dialogues.text: Neil Young, Live at Canterbury House. Thanks for the tip.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Anytime. Edison takes a seat. Rani quickly pulls out her other ear as Julia rushes in with an OVERNIGHT BAG. Throws it under her desk and turns to the class.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Sorry I’m late. Now, get your Valentines and let’s open them. The kids run to their Valentines envelopes on the wall. T them down and run back to their seats. Excitement buildin Although Julia has a stack on her desk from the students, prefers to watch the kids open theirs. Madison has the largest stack of Valentines, the most pop student in the room. Rani only has a few. They’ve all bee opened, but Rani has no reaction. Madison and Kara watch Rani, perplexed. When, Madison stands up and loudly says to the class:

dialogues.speaker: MADISON
dialogues.text: Did everyone check carefully inside their envelopes for ALL of their Valentines? Julia looks at Madison, suspicious. But the students do w Madison says. Rani turns her envelope upside down and out falls the big Valentine, caught on a staple. She opens it  2/18/9 51. Looks over at Edison, his back to her. Rani can’t believe it: Edison. Her face takes on the glow of the windswept sun. Rani gets out of her chair, starts walking towards him, h smile growing, when... From behind her, Madison and Kara start laughing. Rani turns, looks back at Madison and Kara, who are laugh cruelly. Rani realizes. The sun fades.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Rani? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: RANI
dialogues.text: Nothing, Miss Persinger.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Bring the Valentine up here, please. Rani hesitates, then starts to crumple it in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Now, please. Rani reluctantly approaches and hands it to her. Julia re it. Looks at Edison.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Edison? Shocked as hell, he says:

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Yes, ma’am?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Did you send this Valentine to Rani? Edison is horrified and now upset. Realizing Rani is the butt of a joke.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: No, ma’am. I did not.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Madison. Kara. Come up to the front of the class, please. And bring your Valentines with you.  2/18/9 52. Madison and Kara get up. Bring their Valentines. Julia pu her trash can on top of her desk.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You sent Rani this Valentine and signed it from Edison, didn’t you? Both look at her. But say nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: When there’s that much silence, I know you’re thinking up a lie.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: (bursting) She made me do it! Madison looks at Kara, furious. Reed enters the classroom quietly, carrying a single arrangement of two dozen red roses. Julia doesn’t see him. Many of the students do, however, Reed puts a finger to his lips. Shhh.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Madison. Take all of your Valentines and bring them up here. If you’re good you might get them back at the end of the day. Kara, I’m afraid this goes for you, too.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: But I told the truth! Both girls angrily and tearfully give up their Valentines

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: It’s not nice to play with people's hearts like that. When a cough comes behind Julia:

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Julia? Julia turns, surprised. Happy to see him.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Reed? What are you doing here? Edison, recognizing Reed, thinks he’s delivering the rose ordered that morning. He stands up, excited.  2/18/9 53.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: This order came in at the store today. I thought I’d deliver it myself. Reed puts the roses on Julia’s desk. Edison looks confuse Reed was supposed to give him the flowers. She opens the card, hoping. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: It’s from Harrison.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Your boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Yes. Edison sits back down, shocked. Not his flowers. He is no happy. Reed looks at her shining face, knows he should tell her truth. He looks at the classroom -- all the kids staring the interaction of their teacher with the flower man.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Julia. There’s something I have to tell you. Can I see you outside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reed looks at Julia, trying to find the words. But Julia’ got plenty of her own.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Wait. Me first. I got a 4:15 flight to San Francisco. I’m gonna surprise him. But Reed doesn’t look so happy.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What’s with the face? You were into this idea before.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: I was. I mean...I don’t know. I met Harrison when he came in and placed the order.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You did? Wow. He must’ve been on his way to the airport. Isn’t he great?  2/18/9 54.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: (haltingly) Sure, sure. But, you know, people are so - complex, right? And there’s always more to the story --

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You think he’s too old for me. But - listen - I’ve had a lot of bad experiences with guys my age, and even though - When EDISON bursts through the doors. Frantic. He grabs Reed’s shirt. Calls him by the store’s name.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Mr. Flora. What about my roses? Reed's blank, trying to place him out of the environment.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: I gave you thirteen dollars! Reed puts an arm on Edison’s shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. I remember now. They must still be on the truck, little man. Don’t worry, they’1ll get here soon.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: You promised me. Fifth period. I chose you because you were on TV this morning when I was writing my Valentines. It was a sign. Julia kneels down, consoles him.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Edison. If Reed says your roses will be here, then they will. He's very trustworthy. She smiles, steers Edison into the classroom. As the classroom door shuts -

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Don’t get on that plane today. It’s a mistake. Julia stops.  2/18/9 55.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What? You said you liked spontaneous.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: I do, but-- Reed looks at her, trying to say it. But she seems so hap so hopeful, he just can’t. So he says nothing. Julia smil at his concern.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Look Reed, I get it. You've had six girlfriends since we’ve known each other - you’re always ina relationship. You understand how these things work. My track record - on the other hand - could kindly be referred to as spotty. But this one feels different. So don’t worry. I'll be fine. Now I gotta get back to class. She goes in, shutting the door. Leaving Reed alone, with idea what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His buddies work at breakneck speed around him as Jason t on his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: So you can take us? Thank god - that’s great. He grabs a pen.

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: At four? As in four in the afternoon? Even my Nana doesn’t eat dinner at 4. So, it’s 4 or 11:20? I think I might keep looking. He hangs up. Danny and Jed look at him with pity.

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? Not every table at every restaurant can be booked? What about the shitty restaurants? Nobody’s gonna book those.  2/18/9 56.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Maybe don’t pitch it to Liz like that. Jason shoots him a look.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: It’s fine. And I just nabbed tickets for the outdoor movie at Hollywood Forever Cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Girls love cemeteries on Valentine’s Day.

dialogues.speaker: JED
dialogues.text: What about the gift?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I thought of that. I’m gonna go get her a grande white mocha this afternoon. She loves those. Jed and Danny share a look.

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? I’m supposed to get her a Prius? We haven’t even been together three weeks.

dialogues.speaker: JED
dialogues.text: Dude, whatever. Dump her, I don’t care. I’m just saying - if you're gonna do Valentine’s day... Jason considers this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reed drives. Alphonso sits in the passenger seat, scannin clipboard. Reed makes an abrupt left turn.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Just making a quick stop at my house -

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: But we're really behind - Reed pulls the van over in front of his house, puts it in park.  2/18/9 57.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: I know but - Reed reaches into the back of the van and pulls out GIUSEPPE’S BLACK BOX.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: - we’re in the neighborhood and I wanna put these flowers out before my bride-to-be comes home. You know - surprise her. I'’11 be fast.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: Fine. Reed opens the door, takes the black box, and hops out. Then, through the window -

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Oh, by the way. I didn’t tell Julia about Harrison. Reed starts to walk away. Alphonso calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: What? She needs to know, Reed. Reed stops, halfway up his walk.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: I tried. I couldn’t do it to her. I just - don’t think it’s my place. Alphonso just looks at him, not hiding his disapproval.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: We're really behind.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Be right back.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Reed goes to the door, pulls out his keys. But as he trie to put them in, the door just SWINGS OPEN. Reed looks confused. Warily enters the house... INT. REED BENNETT’S HOUSE - SAME Reed looks around as he enters. Calls out:

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Hello?  2/18/9 58. Nothing. As he starts toward the kitchen, he hears from upstairs:

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Reed? Reed is perplexed. He turns and heads toward the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Reed reaches the top of the stairs, still holding the bla box, and turns into the:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morley sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY
dialogues.text: Hey. Reed just stands there, looking at her, not knowing what say. She does not look happy.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: What are you doing home? Morley doesn’t say anything. As he starts to approach her he sees the CLOSET DOOR IS OPEN. AND THE CLOSET IS EMPTY. He stops. He looks at Morley. Then to her packed suitcase on the floor. It’s all starting to make sense.

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry Reed. Reed stands there, in shock, holding the black box.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: It’s not the ring. It’s me. She looks at him, and though it appears to pain her, she doesn’t argue.

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY
