dialogues.text: I’m so sorry. I should have been honest this morning. It just - it took me by surprise, and I didn’t want to hurt you. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MORLEY (cont'd) No one prepares girls for how to handle that scenario. They prepare us to say yes, not how to gracefully say no. Reed is clearly trying to remain upbeat.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Look, it’s fine. If you’re not ready, that’s OK. We can take the whole marriage thing off the table. Maybe I shouldn’t have surprised you like that - we’ve only been together a year - maybe we should have talked about it -- She stops him.

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY
dialogues.text: You didn’t do anything wrong. And it shouldn’t have been a surprise to me. I should have been thinking about our future, too. But I wasn’t. I was just coasting, knowing in my heart that we were not gonna go the distance. And that is not fair to you. You deserve a lot better than that. Morley takes the engagement ring from her pocket, hands i Reed. He studies the ring for a moment, then finally look up at Morley.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Did you even consider marrying me? Even for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: MORLEY
dialogues.text: Of course. But when you ask someone to marry you - do you want her to consider it? Or should she just know the answer? Off Reed, letting that sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reed gets back into the van, still holding the black box. Alphonso looks at him. He’s clearly upset. They sit there for a long, quiet moment.  2/18/9 60.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: You’re not gonna believe this. Morley was in there. She’s leaving me. We’re not getting married. Alphonso looks at him. Doesn’t say anything. But he doesn look surprised. Reed starts to lose it.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: So this you believe? You don’t believe it when she says yes but you believe it when she moves out? Alphonso shrugs, not saying anything.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: You knew?

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: I had a feeling.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: What feeling?

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: That it just wasn’t right. An inkling.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: An inkling? Why didn’t you say something?

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: I didn’t know for sure. Reed takes this in, trying to process. Then something daw on him.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: But I do.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: With Julia. I know something isn’t right.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: Yes you do. Reed starts the van, puts it in gear.  2/18/9 61.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: I’ve gotta stop her.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Wait - I thought we were behind?

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: For this? Screw it. Alphonso smiles. Reed quickly pulls away. INT. CRESCENT ELEMENTARY SCHOOL - JULIA’S CLASSROOM - DAY THE BELL RINGS - the school day is over. Students race ou of the classroom. Free. Julia smiles from the front of th class.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Have a lovely Valentine’s Day guys. She quickly grabs her overnight bag from under her desk, starts for the door. Clearly in a hurry. Edison watches her leave, perturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Julia walks down the hallway, her CELL PHONE RINGS. Sh grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Kara!

dialogues.speaker: INT. D/D/K PR
dialogues.text: Kara sits at her desk, in her huge corner office overlook Beverly Hills, staring at her computer screen.

dialogues.speaker: KARA, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Why haven’t you called me back?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I am so sorry. Today’s been nuts.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: So I’m assuming you didn’t RSVP for my dinner because you come every year and it’s a given that you'll be there, right?  2/18/9 62. Julia keeps walking, not understanding the seriousness of Kara’s question.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Actually, unfortunately, I will not. Be there. I’m flying up to San Francisco to surprise Harrison. Silence. Kara just sits there, trying to hold it together Julia stops at the front door of the school.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you OK sweetie?

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: No one’s coming.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What? That can’t be true.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Well, it is.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What about Dana?

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: New boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What about Elise?

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Back with old boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: NO! Rick?

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Gay cruise to Cabo. Julia stands there, trying to think of what to say.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: So everyone responded “no”?

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: No. There’s still a bunch of people who've looked at it but haven't responded.  2/18/9 63.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Well then I’m sure it’s fine. You know how bad people are about RSVPing. EDISON comes down the hall, walking past Julia and pickin this last bit of their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And it’s not like they don’t know the drill. We’ve been doing it for years - Anarkali at 8. People will come. We see Edison take note of what Julia has said as he walk out of the school. Kara just sits there. She has nothing to say.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m really sorry honey.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: I know. Have fun. Kara hangs up. Rubs her face as she tries not to cry. WITH JULIA - as she hangs up her phone, feeling terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edison races out the doors, past other STUDENTS, pulling from the crowd. He frantically looks and finds a car he recognizes. Spots it. Grabs open the passenger side door. Gets inside. INT. JANICE’S TOYOTA CAMRY - DAY Inside the car, Edison reaches over to the ignition, trie start the car for Janice, his nanny.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Go, go.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Not until you breathe. Like I taught you. Edison sees she’s serious. He forces himself to breathe, using the kundalini yoga warm-up technique of closing one nostril with the thumb and deep breathing in, out.  2/18/9 64.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Okay. I’m breathing.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Now why don’t you tell me what’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: She doesn’t know I love her. I have to make it right. You have to help me or I’m lost. I’m just lost.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Edison. You’re not lost.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Yes, I am. She didn’t get her flowers. She doesn’t know -

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Look, I’m sure this little girl -

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: She’s not a little girl.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: OK. I’m sorry. That was patronizing. I know how you hate to be patronized.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: I do. I hate it. Now will you help me?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Iwill. After soccer.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: I don’t like soccer.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Nobody likes soccer. Edison looks at Janice, resigned.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Fine. Janice starts the car and pulls out.  2/18/9 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelvin and his camera crew interview a MALE employee of T Grove movie theatre. He’s in uniform, a mix between a ban uniform and a bellhop, complete with red hat. The “dancin water fountain is behind him in the background.

dialogues.speaker: GROVE EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: It’s pretty busy at the movies, yeah. We have to patrol more. People like to have sex in the back row. Sometimes with other people. Sometimes with themselves. Exasperated, Kelvin turns and looks directly into the cam Then he composes himself, continuing the interview:

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: What do you think of Valentine’s Day?

dialogues.speaker: GROVE EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: V-Day rhymes with D-Day. Coincidence? I think not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason stands at the counter of the upscale gift store, talking with a MALE CLERK, 20s and hip.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: How much cash do you want to drop?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I don’t really know.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: What do you want the gift to say to your woman?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I’m not really sure. The CLERK is really trying to understand.

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have no idea what I’m doing. I’ve been going out with this girl for like two and a half weeks. But then today I was getting a little bit of a brush-offy vibe. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I say going out, but if you want to get really technical about it, we've never actually said we were going out - so it may still just be in the hanging out category. We've slept together once- and I realize I’m oversharing - but I guess that might not really mean anything. And then we work together, so that’s another wrinkle. The clerk takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: It’s OK, man. Let me help you. You're taking her out tonight, right? Jason nods.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sweet. So what you need to do is read the vibe when you get there. Jason nods again.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you can tell that she is not feeling you at all - The clerk reaches into the case and grabs a SMALL SILVER CASE.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You bust this out. Silver business card holder. Definitely sends a "I can tell this isn’t gonna work out, but we still work together and I want to be respectful” message.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Okay... The clerk reaches into the case again -

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: But if it’s going good, and she’s flirting you up, you whip out this one. He shows Jason a TINY SILVER LOCKET.  2/18/9 67.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Feminine. Delicate. I’ve hit this up on like four girls.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: So, you want me to buy two gifts?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: I’m hooking you up, bro. Don’t worry. Bring back the one you don’t use and I’1l totally refund it. Jason smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: That is a fantastic idea. The clerk beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reed and Alphonso fly up Highland toward the Burbank Airp

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: Try her again. Reed quickly dials his cel phone. Puts it to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Shit. Straight to voicemail again. Reed shoots Alphonso a look, steps harder on the gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Julia’s cel phone as it sits in a plastic bin, the conveyor belt at the security check point. Pull back wide to reveal: Julia, shoes off, ticket in han walking through the metal detector. Happy as can be despi the madness of the travellers around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Griffith Park. Glorious. Picnics. A carousel. Janice is sitting on a crowded grassy hill watching Edison play soc Edison is not into it, missing a pass. He wants the game over. A PLAYER on his team comes up and shoves him for th error. Edison just takes it.  2/18/9 68.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: (to the Player) Can’t you see my heart is broken? The PLAYER can’t quite believe his ears. Then runs past h with the rest of the team to the other side of the field. Edison stays right where he is, the lone man on the cente the field. Finally, the COACH calls time out. Walks up to Edison. Friendly hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: COACH
dialogues.text: What’s the matter, Edison?

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Sporting events, such as these, feel trivial at the moment, Coach. The Coach has no response for that.

dialogues.speaker: WITH JANICE
dialogues.text: As she sits on the grassy hill. Her PHONE BUZZES. She loo at it: a NEW TEXT from Alex. It reads: LOOK BEHIND YOU. Janice turns around, but sees nothing but the beginning o wooded area about 10 feet behind her. She texts back: WHA She watches Edison meander around the field for a second before she gets another text: LOOK CLOSER. She turns around again, this time scanning the wooded are Then she sees Alex, standing at the tree line, waving her over. She looks quite confused. She checks on Edison, who’s sti moping through his soccer game, then gets up and walks ov to Alex.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on? He gives her a mischievous look and beckons her into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janice follows Alex farther into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Where are we going?  2/18/9 69.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: So, you know how I said I'd figure something out?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: (wary) Yeah... As they come up to a small clearing -

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Well - Janice sees how Alex has figured it out - he’s fashioned BED IN THE MIDDLE OF THE WOODS with pillows, blankets, sleeping bags, etc. He’s put some colorful flowers all around. It’s actually kinda cool. But Janice is not impressed.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: This is your big idea?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: You want me to do it here? In the woods?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: It’s rustic. And romantic. It’s romantically rustic.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: With random people 20 feet away?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No I checked. I’ve been screaming obscenities for an hour. There’s no way they can hear us.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: So, let me get this straight. You really thought that I was going to come back here in the woods and have SEX WITH YOU, outdoors, while I left alone the 10 year old boy who I’m responsible for? Just left him alone out there? You thought that would be fun for me? You think that’s romantic? Alex realizes the holes in his plan.  2/18/9 70.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (meekly) I promised I’d figure it out. Janice looks at him, seething.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: You know - for a valedictorian you are a HUGE IDIOT! With that Janice turns and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rita Flora van flies into LAX, passing the Encounter restaurant, the alien arches beaming red instead of blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reed runs into the United Terminal. Looks up at the departing monitors. Finds Julia’s 4:15 flight. Gate 82. Reed runs through the terminal, squeezing past irritated passengers until he’s stopped short.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY
dialogues.text: Only ticketed passengers beyond this point, sir. Reed turns around. Sees: AT THE UNITED TICKET COUNTER Long lines. Reed can’t wait. He sees the OVERSIZED ITEMS AND LIVE ANIMALS section, apart from the regular lines, w there is only one customer. He runs over there.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: I need a ticket on any flight that leaves from Gate C. Preferably your cheapest.

dialogues.speaker: UNITED TICKET AGENT
dialogues.text: This line is for oversized items only.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: But you can sell me a ticket, right? If you wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: UNITED TICKET AGENT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, sir. This line is for --  2/18/9 71.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Look, I know what this seems like. I’m just some other shlemiel who cheated on his girlfriend, and now he’s here with his sob story, begging you to let him go chase the girl down and tell her how it was all a big misunderstanding and that the email with all the naked pictures was actually just a gag by one of his fraternity buddies. The ticket agent looks vaguely disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: UNITED TICKET AGENT
dialogues.text: That's a terrible story.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Right? So let me tell you my story. The girl I’m running to catch isn’t even my girlfriend. But I have to tell her that her boyfriend - they guy she’s about to get on a plane and surprise - is married. And it’s a crappy thing to hear. But I have to do it because it’s the right thing to do. Because she’s a great girl and she'd even take a cigar band from a guy - and I know I’m getting a little off track here, but my point is - I have to go get her. Compared to the earlier story, the ticket agent likes thi one. He starts punching the keys of his computer.

dialogues.speaker: AT GATE 82
dialogues.text: Julia, wearing a simple black dress and flats, stands, overnight bag on the ground next to her. She shifts feet. Excited. She’s never done anything like this before.

dialogues.speaker: UNITED GATE AGENT
dialogues.text: Now boarding group three. All those in group three may now come forward. Julia moves into the line. Then feels a hand on her arm. She turns. It’s Reed.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Reed? What are you doing here? Reed, out of breath. Spits out:  2/18/9 72.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: I need to talk to you. Julia looks around, still trying to process this odd scen

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Okay. So... But then he hesitates. Here she is. But how do you start? Where do you start? So he just says it.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: He’s married.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Your boyfriend. Harrison.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: He was married. He’s divorced now.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: No, Julia. He lives in Malibu with his wife, Alexandra. He came into Rita Flora today and sent you both red roses.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What does that prove? He could’ve just been doing it to be nice.

dialogues.speaker: UNITED GATE AGENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We are now boarding all sections. All sections, please come forward. Julia just looks at him. Hurt.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this? Reed thinks about that, then -

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Do you think Morley and I belong together?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What? What does that have to do with anything?

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: It just - does. Do you?  2/18/9 73.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I guess - if you love her and she loves you then -

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: You’re not answering the question. Honestly - as my friend -

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Fine. No. Not really. Don’t see it. Don’t see you two together.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Well that’s why I’m doing this. Because apparently everyone and their mother knew I shouldn’t propose to her, but no one had the guts to say anything - and now she’s gone and I’m left with this stupid ring and an empty closet and I don’t want you to make the same mistake I did. Don’t pursue a dead end Julia. It hurts like hell. Julia stares at him, trying to process this. She’s not having it.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: You are unbelievable. You expect me to buy that - that you’re trying to help me? You’re just doing this because - for once - I have something and you have nothing. And you just can’t take it. You want me to feel as bad as you do.

dialogues.speaker: UNITED GATE AGENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Last call for all sections. Now boarding all sections on United Flight 954 to San Francisco. Reed doesn’t know what to say. He wasn’t expecting that. Julia picks up her overnight bag.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Honestly - as a friend - this is a really shitty thing to do to someone.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Don’t get on that plane. Julia. Think. Didn’t you know? Somewhere? We always know, right?  2/18/9 74. He grabs her hand. But somehow, it’s the touch that break her. She pulls away from his grasp.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: It’s Valentine’s Day and I’m going to meet my boyfriend. Now let me go. She walks away. He watches her as she hands her ticket to the Agent. The stub shoots through the machine at the oth end. She doesn’t turn around. Disappears down the tunnel. Reed throws his ticket in the trash can. Walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the cramped bathroom stall, a nervous female hand pulls out a lipstick. Her hands shaking. Pull back to reveal a face looking into the mirror, putti it on: It’s Kate, not Julia. Kate pulls out a sealed tube of mascara and some blush. S carefully puts them on. Now looking quite feminine and beautiful in her military uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kate returns to her seat. Holden, watching a movie, has t pause his screen and let her back into her seat. As he do he notices:

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: You look pretty.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: Are you nervous?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: He’1l be waiting for you, I promise. She looks at him, slightly vulnerable now.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: The hardest thing about coming home is realizing people have moved on. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATE (cont'd) They've lived a part of their lives without you, memories you'll never have with them.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: Do you get to call him?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Sometimes, when we’re in range. But the time difference makes it hard. Plus, what can you really say in three minutes - with your whole platoon full of guys standing around?

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: Maybe just that you love him? Kate looks at him, touched by his earnestness.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Yeah. I say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelvin, with his camera crew, stands on the street corner interviewing a chubby male CUPID, wearing white diapers, white wings with gold bows and arrows slung over his shou and eating a submarine sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: CUPID
dialogues.text: I make a lot of dough today. Delivering love grams to office buildings and such. It’s a great day for a fat guy. So, yeah, I love Valentine’s Day.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: So you're saying today is about money?

dialogues.speaker: CUPID
dialogues.text: It sure as hell is. You ever NOT spend money on Valentine’s Day? I even delivered a break-up gram today. Now that was cold, sure, but I still got paid! Kelvin calls cut. To his crew:

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: I think we got it. The CAMERAMAN starts to pack up his stuff.  2/18/9 76.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERAMAN
dialogues.text: Where to next? As Kelvin thinks about it, he looks across the street to LARGE OFFICE BUILDING. He’s got an idea.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: You know what - I think we’re done. Just pack up the van. I’11 be right back. With that, Kelvin takes off across the street. INT. D/D/K PR - KARA’S OFFICE - AFTERNOON Kelvin comes blowing into Kara’s office, trailed by JAN, Kara’s assistant.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN JAN
dialogues.text: Kara, I’m sorry to bother you- I told him you were very b Kara looks up from her desk, EYES WET WITH TEARS. Kelvin Jan stop in their tracks.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to -

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: It’s OK. Sit down. (to Jan) It’s fine. Jan backs out of the office. Kelvin takes a seat on the couch. Kara tries to pull herself together.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: So - I know you said there wasn't much chance, but I - She cuts him off.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Let me ask you a question Kelvin. What are your plans for tonight? Kelvin seems confused.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Umm - I really just came here to try and get the exclusive with Sean - but -  2/18/9 77.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: No - I know. And I’m not asking you out or anything. It just seems like literally everyone on earth has something to do tonight so - Kelvin looks at her, gauging her seriousness.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: I’m working. 5pm, 10pm and 1lpm newscasts. I usually only do one of those, but everyone wanted off tonight and I’m more than happy to oblige. It’s one of the perks of having a night job - there’s always excuse not to participate in all this ridiculousness. Kara gives a small smile, satisfied by the answer. She ge up, walks over to the couch, sits next to Kelvin.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: I haven’t had a date on Valentine's day in almost 10 years. I mean - it’s mostly by choice. I put all my energy into this job, into taking care of my clients - and I know I don’t put myself out there at all - but still - 10 years. Isn't that pathetic?

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. I don’t think I’ve ever had one. Again, by choice, but -

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: The thing that I hate most about this day - honestly - is that I’m embarrassed. I’m embarrassed that it makes me feel as bad about being alone as it does. Kara starts to tear up again. She puts her head in her hands, now really crying. Kelvin sits there, not knowing what to do. He puts his ARM AROUND HER, and she sinks int him, sobbing now. After a few moments, her crying subsides. She pulls back from Kelvin, wipes her eyes, now embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: KARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m really sorry. I don’t even know you.  2/18/9 78. She gets up and goes back to her desk. He gets up as well in a bit of shock.

dialogues.speaker: KARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyway - I’m sending word out now that Sean’s press conference will be at 6 at the Century Plaza.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Oh. OK.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Sorry you came all this way for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: No. It was - no problem. Kelvin looks at her, mind searching for something else to say. He comes up with nothing. So he just turns and goes. INT. EDGAR & ESTELLE’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - DAY Edison and Janice stand in the kitchen. Edgar and Estelle both sit at the kitchen table, phone in Estelle’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: (still upset) Tomorrow is not gonna work.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: They weren't taking any new orders, dear. She’ll get them tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: But tomorrow is too late! It has to be today! Edison runs out of the room, the sound of his bedroom doo slamming echoes down the hall. Silence in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: He’ll be fine. Today is a lot of pressure for anyone, let alone such a young boy.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Tell me about it. Estelle looks at Janice, reading her face.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: Everything OK with you and Alex?  2/18/9 79. Janice looks at them, deciding whether to open up. She pu out a chair, sits at the table.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: It’s what hasn’t happened, actually. OK - you guys promise - no judgement?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: Sweetie it’s us - of course not. Janice takes a breath and then dives in.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Alex and I were supposed to have sex today. For the first time. Both of us for the first time. Edgar and Estelle share a look, careful not to show any judgement.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And it was supposed to be - magical. But I’m realizing now how hard it is to plan something magical.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: That it is.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: I just wanted something special to carry us through, you know? He’s going to Stanford, I’m going to Yale - it’s going to be nearly impossible to stay together. These things never work out. I know that. But I just thought if we had something really amazing connecting us that we might have a better shot. Janice stops, takes stock of what’s she’s been saying. JANICE (CONT’D) And now - saying it all out loud - I just feel stupid. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANICE (CONT’D) Like - what, I’m going to sleep with just one person in my entire life? That’s just - preposterous. Who does that? A small smile comes across Edgar’s face. He looks to Estelle, then back to Janice.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: We did. Janice looks at them in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: No. Edgar nods proudly. JANICE (CONT’D) That's amazing.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Now, granted, it was a different time. People married earlier, and weren’t as promiscuous as they are now. They were more promiscuous than the movies of the time would lead you to believe, but still... Edgar looks to Estelle, trying to bring her into the conversation, but she looks - odd. She’s staring off, not meeting his eye. Edgar continues.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And we went through several periods where we were apart - months where I was away on business or Estelle was off on location - and we managed to make it through. As Edgar keeps talking, tears begin to well up in Estelle eyes. He’s oblivious, while Janice becomes aware somethin is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, I’m not saying it was easy, or even that it’s something that you should do. But just that it’s possible. And it’s the thing I’m most proud of. Being faithful to one woman is the greatest accomplishment of my life.  2/18/9 81. Edgar finishes, smiling, but Janice is now focused on Estelle, who has tears running down her face.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: Janice. I hate to do this to you again, but can you take the boy out for awhile?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Um, I don’t know. I have class tonight... Janice looks at Estelle, sees what she’s going through. JANICE (CONT’D) You know what, it’s fine. I/’11 - skip it. Janice gets up and heads toward Edison’s room. Estelle ta Edgar’‘s hands. He looks confused and scared.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Honey, what is it? She looks at him, not saying anything. He looks back at h waiting. Then, he just - knows. He gets up and walks out of the ro INT. EDISON’S ROOM - SAME Janice opens the door to Edison's bedroom, but he’s nowhe to be seen.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Edison? She opens the closet, checks under the bed - nothing. The she notices it - THE OPEN WINDOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edison walks briskly down Wilshire, heading east, backpac his back. A few passersby give him an odd look, this kid for a stroll by himself, but he doesn’t even notice. He’s a mission. INT. EDGAR & ESTELLE’S HOUSE - HALLWAY - AFTERNOON Janice stands outside the closed door to Edgar and Estell room, about to knock. Through the door she can hear the muffled sound of an unmistakably serious conversation goi on inside. She thinks better of knocking, pulls her hand down. She’ll have to deal with this herself.  2/18/9 82. She moves quickly down the hall and out the front door. INT. EDGAR & ESTELLE’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - AFTERNOON Edgar is packing a suitcase. His hands shaking. Estelle stands in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: You were in Mexico, building those new apartment complexes, and I was alone with a two-year-old. Michael used to come over, just to help. You have no idea how much you need to talk to an adult after days of being with a child, and --

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Michael? You had an affair with my business partner?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: It was only one night. One night, Edgar. And we both regretted it.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: I called you every day, even when I was so exhausted I couldn’t even stand up long enough to take a shower. I still called. His movements are shaky. Estelle moves forward, puts her arms around his waist.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: I’ve only loved one man in my life. You.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Then why do this? Why tell me now?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: Because I wanted you to know the truth. He closes the suitcase, snaps the locks. Faces her.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Sad fact is, Estelle, the truth makes everything else seem like a lie. The look on his face is so final. He walks out the door.  2/18/9 83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelvin sits in the makeup chair, tissue covering his suit The HAIR AND MAKEUP TEAM put on the finishing touches. Susan appears at the door, takes in the scene.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Happy to be back doing what you love? Kelvin looks at her in the mirror, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Today wasn’t so bad. Susan takes a few steps in, perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Really? Well, I’m glad you enjoyed yourself. Because it was pretty bad on my end.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: How’s that?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? I ask you for love and romance and what do you give me? A guy removing tatoos? Sex in movie theatres? A giant rat? Kelvin looks at her in the mirror, trying to figure out w to say.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Look, Susan - I tried. I wanted it to come out differently - but this is just what presented itself.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Bullshit. You found what you wanted to find. Susan backs up, annoyed. SUSAN (CONT’D) You were right. I thought you were capable of more - but I guess not. You should definitely just stick to sports.  2/18/9 84. With that, she leaves. Kelvin shares a look with the Hair Guy, guilty. INT. JULIA’S CAR - EARLY EVENING Close on Julia, still in her black dress, as she drives. face is quiet, still. Almost as if she’s trying to hold o this moment -- before anything is truly known and she’s forced to change. INT. HOSPITAL - NURSES’ STATION - EARLY EVENING Labor & Delivery. Julia walks up to the nurses’ station. FILIPINO NURSE smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I’m looking for Dr. Copeland?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: He’s not here right now.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Can you tell me where he is?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Are you a patient? Is something wrong? Julia just looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: May I ask you something, woman to woman?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Is Dr. Copeland married? Not divorced or separated or living apart. Or anything like that. But flat out married to a woman named Alexandra that he lives with in Malibu? The Nurse looks at her, realizing.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Yes. 15 years. And he has a daughter. Her shoulders drop, she releases her breath. Starts to tu away. But the Nurse stops her.  2/18/9 85.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Crustacean. 7 pm. Julia looks up at the clock. It’s 6:35 p.m.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: EVENING
dialogues.text: Julia, in her car, still in her black dress, flies out of parking structure for the LA hospital. Letting us know no she’s in Los Angeles, not San Francisco. Overnight bag in the seat beside her. She never got on th plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A simple triplex. Fenced in by chain link. Not a great neighborhood. When the Rita Flora Delivery Van pulls up. Reed is still driving. Alphonso is ASLEEP the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reed looks at Alphonso, totally PASSED OUT. He smiles, shakes him gently on the shoulder. Alphonso stirs.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Get out. Go inside and be with your wife.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: It’s fine. She knew I'd be working late.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: So, surprise her. Someone around here should have a happy Valentine’s day. Alphonso looks at him a moment, and nods.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you let her get on that plane.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: I did everything I could to stop her.  2/18/9 86.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: But it doesn’t make sense. She didn’t even want to go.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: And how do you know that? Another inkling.

dialogues.speaker: ALPHONSO
dialogues.text: Yeah. But maybe I’m off. I’m real tired. Alphonso Junior just got the Guitar Hero with the drumset for his birthday. That was a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Go. Be with your family. He pats Reed on the shoulder, gets out of the car. Walks the path to his front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beverly Hills. A giant lobster hanging in the center. The height of expensive Valentine’s Day prix fixe dinners. Harrison sits at a candlelit table with his wife, Alexand

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDRA
dialogues.text: Olivia's going to need braces.

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: Genetic. You needed them. I needed them. She needs them. Julia walks in, her simple black dress is now BULGING. Sh suddenly NINE MONTHS PREGNANT. She waddles, putting her hands behind her hips, thrusting her fake belly out. She spots Harrison and Alexandra, in a corner booth. Almo loses her nerve. But she keeps going. Midway, Harrison sees her. His eyes widen slightly, then quickly recovers his smooth composure. Julia reaches the table. And then DOUBLES OVER.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Oh my god. Oh my god! Not now.

dialogues.speaker: NOT NOW, GOD
dialogues.text: Alexandra immediately gets up and goes to her.  2/18/9 87.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDRA
dialogues.text: Are you OK?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I’ve never had a baby before. Julia DOUBLES OVER again.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Ooooh! That was a big KICK! Alexandra looks a little confused.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDRA
dialogues.text: Oh, is he just kicking, or are you having contractions?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What? Oh, umm, both. Kicks and contractions. But mostly contractions. Like BAD ones.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDRA
dialogues.text: Are you here alone? Julia looks at Harrison.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m alone. Again.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDRA
dialogues.text: OK. You’re gonna be OK. My husband is a doctor. He delivers babies all the time. Harrison is frozen in his seat. Alexandra looks at Harris

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDRA
dialogues.text: Harrison! A little help... He starts to gets up. Reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Oh, no. I don’t want to interrupt your romantic meal with your WIFE. I‘1l be just fine. She goes to walk off, and then:

dialogues.speaker: PEAS AND CARROTS
dialogues.text: She holds her tummy in mock pain.  2/18/9 88.

dialogues.speaker: ALEXANDRA
dialogues.text: Harrison! Help the woman. Would you like to sit? Julia is writhing around in front of their table.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry. I really don’t want to interrupt your sexy Valentine’s day thing here - Julia JOLTS again, making a big show of grabbing her bell Even doing some dramatic breathing.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Man, this little guy just will not let up. Harrison finally takes charge:

dialogues.speaker: HARRISON
dialogues.text: Ma’am, what often helps in the early stages of contractions is a brisk walk. Why don’t I take a little stroll with you, and I can time your contractions as we go. That way I can give you a better sense of where you stand. Julia looks right at him. Stops the act.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: That’s OK. I think I know exactly where I stand. Goodbye Dr. Copeland. Julia turns and heads off, walking confidently towards th door, Harrison shrinking behind her. She stops at the hostess stand, where the hostess holds T GIANT SHOPPING BAGS, full of takeout containers.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: And we'll just charge these to ...

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: To my friend over there. She turns and WAVES to Harrison who, though confused, WAV BACK. The hostess hands her the BAGS.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Thank you. And Happy Valentine's day.  2/18/9 89. She pulls the pillow out of her shirt, hands it to the hostess, and leaves with a SMILE GROWING ON HER FACE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason and Liz sit at a TINY table for two, squished in a next to countless other tables for two. The tables are in military rows, way too close to one another, with a BIG T NUMBER marking each one. They both look a little uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Sorry we had to wait so long. That was ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I thought if we got here at 6 it would be pretty empty. A WAITRESS approaches.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: So, would you like our four course sweetheart’s menu, or our eight course eternal love menu?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I don’t know, eternal love sounds kinda nice... Liz checks her watch.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I was thinking more like a salad.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: (to waitress) Maybe you have like a one course ‘just dating’ menu? The waitress doesn’t laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think we need some more time. Jason takes a sip of his water, tries to relax.

dialogues.speaker: DUDE NEXT TO HIM
dialogues.text: Dude - that’s my water.  2/18/9 90.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Sorry. My bad. They really pack us in there, huh? The DUDE glares and slides his water closer. Jason looks Liz, forces a smile, checks out his menu.

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I heard the steaks are great here.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: You know what? I think I’m just gonna have a cocktail. Is that OK? Jason’ tries to cover his disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Yeah. I mean, the menu looks great, and the place is lovely, and I so appreciate you taking me out - but, the thing is, I didn’t know we were going out tonight - and I actually committed to getting back. I was hoping I could do both, but it’s getting late - Jason is stung.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I didn’t realize you had other plans -

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: No, it’s just work --

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: No. It’s cool. I actually have some other plans, too. An awkward beat. Then, Jason reaches into his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I did get you something. And I'd really like for you to have it. He pulls out a SMALL WRAPPED BOX. He hands it to her, expectant.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: You didn’t have to.  2/18/9 91. She opens it. It’s the BUSINESS CARD HOLDER.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: It’s for business cards. For when you get promoted. I thought it was the perfect gift - you know - co- worker to co-worker. Liz looks a little sad.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Oh. OK. Well, co-worker to co- worker, thank you. She reaches across the table and SHAKES HIS HAND. The dat has officially crashed and burned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the hallway outside a conference room, Sean peers thro a cracked door into the room. It’s PACKED with reporters ambling about, eating donuts, etc. He closes the door, leans against the wall, takes a deep breath. Kara and Drew approach, ready to go. Sean straightens up when he sees them.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: So. You sure you don’t want to run by us what you’re gonna say?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: No, I got it.

dialogues.speaker: DREW
dialogues.text: We'd really like to know. Just so we don’t look like fools up there.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: No man. It’s a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: I’m a publicist Sean. I don’t like surprises.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I'm fine. I took the podium as the losing quarterback in the Super Bowl. I can handle this. She looks at him, nods. He begins to pace around, getting prepared.  2/18/9 92.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: OK then. You ready? Sean nods, amped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean stands at the podium, flanked by Kara and Drew. As S collects his notes, Kara scans the crowd. She finds KELVIN - NEAR THE BACK. They meet eyes. He give a small smile. She returns it. Sean looks at his notes, then puts them down. Doesn’t nee them.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (INTO MIC)
dialogues.text: I'd like to thank everyone for coming here tonight. And I’m not gonna waste y’alls time with some long winded thing here - I’m just gonna get to it. The cliche is - when someone’s retiring who really doesn’t want to retire - they say it’s because they want to spend more time with their family. But I don’t have a family. And with everything football has given me - the biggest thing it’s taken away is that. Because of who I am, because of my job, I can’t lead the life I want to. So, with that in mind, I’ll just say the thing I came here to say. Sean looks out over the crowd, gets a huge smile on his f

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m gay. Stunned reaction from the crowd. Drew looks to Kara, who clearly had no idea he was going to say this.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And there’s someone out there, hopefully watching this, who tried to deal with me having to lie for years and finally got fed up. This is for you. I hope you can forgive me. (then) Any questions? And be cool now - I’m not above kicking any of y’alls asses.  2/18/9 93. The reporters all look at each other, no one quite sure w an appropriate question would be. Finally, a hand goes up the back. It’s Kelvin.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Kelvin Briggs - KTLA. I guess I’m a little unclear. Are you retiring?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. Right. That. (he laughs) No. I’m not retiring. Boisterous reaction from the crowd. Bulbs flashing like crazy.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m gay and I’m gonna play. How about that? Sean smiles at the podium as the floodgates open - a cacophony of questions. KELVIN AND KARA MEET EYES across crowd, both clearly moved Sean’s declaration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean exits into the hallway, Kara in tow, insanity still going on in the conference room behind them.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: OK. I’m gonna head back to the office now. We’ll set up interviews - maybe late night shows - and then -

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: Kara - stop. There’s nothing to do. It’s already done. Kara looks at him, taking this in. She gets a huge smile her face.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: She envelops him in a big hug. He hugs her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden and Kate both exit the jetway into the gate. A bit bleary-eyed but happy to have landed.  2/18/9 94. As they walk through the terminal, they come upon a GROUP PEOPLE SURROUNDING A TV. They stop to check it out. ON THE TV - ESPN.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR
dialogues.text: So, Sean Jackson is not retiring. And he also wants you to know something else... They cut to the clip of Sean’s press conference -

dialogues.speaker: SEAN, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: I’m gay. WITH THE CROWD IN THE AIRPORT - as they react enthusiastically. Kate and Holden stare at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Wow. Good for him. Holden smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. They continue through the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden walks out through the sliding glass doors of Bagga Claim. A Driver at his side, pushing his expensive leathe bags on a cart.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE CURB
dialogues.text: Holden turns, looking for Kate. He finds her, standing in the long taxi line. Holden says to the Driver:

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: Just a minute.

dialogues.speaker: LAX DRIVER
dialogues.text: Certainly, sir. Holden walks over to Kate. Taps her gently on her back. S turns around, surprised to see him.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: This is quite a line. Kate looks at him. Her reserve back. A confidant on the plane has now become a stranger in the city.  2/18/9 95.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: It’s moving. Slowly but surely.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: I've got a car - He looks back toward his patiently waiting driver.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: That’s nice of you, but I’m up in the hills - it would be too far out of your way ---

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: That’s not what I mean. You take it. I’1l wait for a cab. You've come so far for just a few hours - Kate starts to tear up.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. It’s paid for. It/’l1l take you wherever you want to go. She looks at him, amazed at his generosity.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Thank you. She envelops him in a huge hug. INT. JANICE’S CAR - NIGHT Janice drives slowly, weaving in and out of the neighborh streets off 6th Street. She peers out the window, looking for Edison, growing more concerned by the second. She pul out her phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Come on Edison, pick up. She waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Edison’s backpack, CEL PHONE RINGING in the sid netted pocket. WIDEN TO: Edison still walking alone, considerably slower than he did at the outset. With all the traffic noise, he doesn’t hear his phone ring.  2/18/9 96. It’s getting dark, and this part of Wilshire looks a litt sketchy when the sun goes down. But as he approaches La Brea, he gets a second wind and puts it into high gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kara pulls up in her Land Rover, gets a ticket from the Valet. She goes around to the passenger side and pulls ou her BIG BAG OF DECORATIONS, shuts the door and heads into restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The New Delhi temple interior of this family-run Indian h is full of exotic fabrics. Red archways. Traditional Indi music plays. Murals of romantic Indian love scenes.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Ten year old student RANI (Edison’s classmate) picks up m empty water glasses when her father, DEECHUM, Indian (30s stops her.

dialogues.speaker: DEECHUM
dialogues.text: Rani. What is wrong? You've been moping all day. Her brother, SHANTUM (14), enters, grabs more napkins.

dialogues.speaker: SHANTUM
dialogues.text: It is Valentine’s Day, Father.

dialogues.speaker: DEECHUM
dialogues.text: Is this about a boy? When it is time, your mother and I will find you a nice Indian boy. Rani walks out, into the restaurant, passing ALEX - the delivery boy - who’s heading out with another delivery.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Cheer up, Rani. I’11 be your Valentine. He gives her a sweet big brother smile.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RESTAURANT
dialogues.text: Kara is now standing on the booth, back to us, aggressive tying off her home-printed banner -- I HATE VALENTINE’S D between the two columns of the booth. She takes a string of hearts, now cut in half, and hangs framing the booth.  2/18/9 97. She takes a look at it, satisfied, and plops down onto th seat. Reaches for a glass of wine, drains it. She looks at the door. And waits. No one. She sits. The banner FALLS OFF OF ONE OF THE COLUMNS BEHI HER. It just hangs there. She doesn’t turn around. Doesn’t even bother to fix it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night. CLOSE on the headstones of dead Hollywood stars. M Blanc, Douglas Fairbanks, Tyrone Power, Bugsy Siegel. The cemetery - where some of old hollywood's biggest star are buried - is filling with couples who spread blankets the lawn, ready to watch the movie projected outside. A S advertises tonight’s movie: PILLOW TALK Jason walks past the tickets line, tickets in hand. As he passes, Edgar makes it to the front of the line.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Just one please.

dialogues.speaker: TICKET VENDOR
dialogues.text: I’m sorry sir. This line is just for will call. We are completely sold out.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: You don’t understand -

dialogues.speaker: TICKET VENDOR
dialogues.text: Here’s our brochure - maybe you can come back for another event. Before Edgar can respond again, Jason swoops in.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: It’s OK. He’s with me. Edgar looks up, Jason holds up TWO TICKETS. He follows Ja out of the ticket line.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, young man.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: No problem. I had an extra.  2/18/9 98.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: It’s Valentine’s Day. There’s got to be a story there. Jason hands TWO TICKETS to the USHER at the entry gate, a they walk in together.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Not a good one.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Not a good story, or not a good ending.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Neither. Edgar gives him a doubtful look.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: This girl I was dating ditched out on me. Like the worst Valentine’s Day story ever.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Oh really? Today I found out my wife cheated on me. Jason looks at him - touche. Edgar holds up a silver flas

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Bourbon? Jason smiles. Definitely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s still busy, mostly men rushing in before they drive home. Reed walks in, still clinging to his BLACK BOX. Not the upbeat Reed we’re used to. He watches as his clerks m quickly and efficiently. Edison enters, exhausted from his walk. He’s so out of breath he can barely talk. But he trudges right up to Ree who can’t believe his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: (between gulps of air) You. Owe. Me. Flowers. Reed looks at him, full of guilt. He looks down to the bo in his hands, gets an idea. Smiles.  2/18/9 99.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Where to? Edison looks at Reed. His face lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kara’s now a few glasses of wine in. The remains of the m she ate surround her. And she’s still by herself. She checks her watch - the look on her face says it’s tim call it quits. She gets up on the booth, her back to the door, and start take down the string of hearts. Then from behind her:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Did I miss the party? Kara turns around to find KELVIN. Standing there. WITH FLOWERS. She can’t help but smile. He can’t either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Edgar and Jason are a little inebriated now. The fil playing in the background.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: So tell me about your girl. Where is she? Jason looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: She said she had to go back to work. But that’s probably bullshit - I mean, it’s probably not the truth -

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: I know what bullshit means, son.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: So she’s probably just blowing me off. As Edgar takes this in, he looks up to the screen to see: ON THE SCREEN: A scene with a young 20 something starlet talking to Rock Hudson on the telephone. Edgar smiles, nudges Jason. Gestures to the screen.  2/18/9 100.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: That’s my girl. Jason looks to the screen - his mouth drops open.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: You're kidding. She was HOT. Edgar nods, still looking at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: She still is.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Wow. You sure you wanna let that go? Edgar looks at the screen, thinks about that.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: You know - I have this story I tell my grandson about how we met. I tell it the same every time - it goes like this: I was nineteen. Estelle was eighteen. I was an architect. I worked in the front office with a big window. She would come out every morning and post the mail. I thought she was the prettiest girl I’d ever seen, so I got up my courage and waited by the postbox to say hello. Only I didn’t say a word because I was afraid. So she pushed me aside, and said, “Move, big fella.” But I kept coming back every day until she agreed to go out with me.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: That’s a nice story.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: It is. Too bad it’s, as you say, bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: I mean, don’t get me wrong, all of that happened. But the part I leave out is what happened after. Our first date was a crushing failure. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDGAR (cont'd) I was so nervous I stalled out my car, forgot my wallet, made horribly awkward conversation - I thought she’d never want to see me again.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: But she did.

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: After a few weeks, yes. But I had put so much pressure on that one date that it was bound to fail. Our second date we went on a walk. That’s it. It wasn’t until we stripped away all expectation that we really began to fall in love. Edgar looks back at the screen, at the beautiful image of young wife. Jason does, too, thinking about what he’s hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kara and Kelvin now sit at the booth talking, the flowers between them. She still can’t stop smiling.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: So wait - how did you find me?

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Your assistant Jan and I have become pretty close today - so - Kara laughs.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Right. They look at each other, not knowing what to say next. Bu it’s not a bad silence - sort of a good hopeful awkward o

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: So - I have to know. Did you know about Sean? I mean - before today. Kara tries to hide her smile.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: I did. I had my suspicions for a while, but he finally told me a few years ago. I think I was one of the only people he ever told. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KARA (cont'd) And I guess I always assumed he’d retire at some point and just fade away - get a chance to lead the life he wanted - but - (she thinks about it) I don’t know. Seeing him up there, doing what he did - it just made me realize -

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: You can have both.

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: Yeah. You can have both. Kara and Kelvin look at each other, a definite connection Which is broken by the door opening. JULIA ENTERS.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I am so sorry I’m late. Kara looks up - can’t believe it. Julia comes over and jo them, still holding the shopping bags from the restaurant

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: I - it doesn’t matter. I’m here now. Kara can tell by the look on her face that it’s not good.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Look, I just - I really don’t wanna talk about it. She starts to unpack the shopping bags - exquisite DESSER from Crustacean, about 20 of them.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Anyway - my contribution to the party. Molten lava chocolate hearts. Normally 100 bucks a pop. But I got a great deal. Kelvin helps her unpack the remaining desserts. As he doe

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Hi. I’m Julia. She extends her hand. He shakes it.  2/18/9 103.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: Kelvin.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: So - Kelvin - how do you come to this sad affair?

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: I’m actually Kara’s date. Julia looks to Kara - who looks as surprised as she does. The DOOR OPENS again, TWO WOMEN RUSH IN, FLUSTERED. It’s DANA AND ELISE (BOTH 30'S). They approach the table. Kara and Julia can’t believe their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: KARA
dialogues.text: (to Dana) Yeah, I thought you were going out with your new boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: (to Elise) And I thought you got back together with your old boyfriend. Dana and Elise share a look. Then, in unison -

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Yeah. You know how restaurants have two seatings on Valentine's Day?

dialogues.speaker: ELISE
dialogues.text: That’s what James was trying to pull off. Julia and Kara look at each other in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Now please. If you don’t mind. Lead me to the alcohol.  2/18/9 104. Julia obliges, pouring them some wine. Kara looks to Kelv who shoots her a smile. She smiles back, taking in her party, which actually didn’t turn out half bad. INT. JANICE’S CAR - NIGHT Janice sits at a stoplight, scanning the intersection, ho for some kind of miracle. As she waits there, a VAN pulls up to her left and stops the light. We can clearly see EDISON SITTING IN THE PASSENGER SEAT, Reed driving. Janice continues to look around the intersection, oblivio to Edison right next to her. But when the light turns green, the van starts to pull aw Janice looks to her left at the last second, catching a glimpse of Edison (who doesn’t see her). Her eyes go WIDE

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: SHIT! NO! You’re not supposed to get into vans! But as the van passes, she sees the RITA FLORA logo, and relaxes a bit. She changes lanes and gets behind the van, following up La Brea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van pulls up, Reed and Edison hop out. As Reed goes t the back to grab the flower, Janice’s car pulls up. She jumps out and makes a bee-line for Edison, who starts apologizing before she can even talk.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: I'm sorry -

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: You can’t do that to me -

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: I know - I know -

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: I’m responsible for you Edison. Do you understand that?

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: I do. But you weren’t - no one was - no one was helping me. I just had to do it myself.  2/18/9 105. Janice looks at him as Reed approaches with the BOX, take the scene.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Everything OK? Edison looks to Janice, hopeful. She softens.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Everything's fine. (then) Do you want me to come in with you?

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: No. Thanks. I made it this far. I want to do this alone.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: OK. Do you have your cel phone? Edison nods.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good. Text me when you’re done and I‘1l pick you up here. Edison nods. He takes the box from Reed.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Thanks Mr. Flora. Reed smiles.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: Anytime. Edison walks to the front of the restaurant and enters. Janice walks back to her car. But Reed just stands there, not sure what to do. Instead of going to his van, he head toward the front door of the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janice pulls around to the back alley behind the restaura She puts the car in park and sits back - turns up the ste Her PHONE BUZZES.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s quick. This can’t be good. She grabs the phone - it’s not from Edison. It’s a NEW TE from Alex: Now?  2/18/9 106. She looks up to see Alex, standing at the back door of th restaurant, delivery bag in hand. She smiles. He does as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar now alone, waiting for the climactic scene in the movie. Watching closely as:

dialogues.speaker: ON THE CRYPT
dialogues.text: The film plays. And it’s Estelle. A young Estelle. Beautiful. A life barely lived. Rapturously kissing Rock Hudson when a BODY stands in front of the crypt, blocking images for the entire audience. Who immediately shouts:

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Get the hell out of the way! Move it! Now! When the body steps fully into the light so we can see he clearly. It’s Estelle.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLE
dialogues.text: Edgar! Edgar! I know you’re here! We come every year! Edgar! More angry voices from the Audience.

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Who the hell is Edgar? Get her the hell outta there! What the --? When the voice returns his call:

dialogues.speaker: EDGAR
dialogues.text: Estelle? Estelle? Over here! Estelle peers into the darkness to find Edgar, waving the silver flask. Edgar starts running to her. The best he can for an older man. She too, makes her way to him.... And they run, dodging headstones. People. Picnic baskets. And they meet. Tears in her eyes. In his. She looks at him. Hopeful. When he takes her into her arms. And kisses her. In perfect sync with the movie playing behind them. INT. JANICE’S CAR - NIGHT Janice and Alex make out with abandon in the back seat of car. Janice pulls back, looks at Alex.  2/18/9 107.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Are you sure you don’t need to deliver that food?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What? No. I mean - eventually. But we’ve got time. Alex goes back to kissing her. She stops.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Because you know how annoyed I get when deliveries take a long time, and I would hate -

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Seriously? Are we talking about this?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: You're right. I’m - just a little nervous.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Sure. Sure. To be expected. They go back to kissing. Janice stops again.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Can you put that bag outside or something. It kind of - smells.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What? I thought you loved the food here.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: I do. It doesn’t smell bad. It just smells. Like Indian food. And I didn’t envision my first time would go down with Saag Paneer wafting around. Alex gets it. He reaches into the front seat, grabs the b opens the door and places it outside. He goes back to kissing her. She stops him again. JANICE (CONT’D) Sorry - again. Can we shift a little? This seat belt is really - jamming -  2/18/9 108. They shift over a little.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - there. Better.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You good?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: I’m good. Just as they’re about to start kissing again, Janice stop Alex one last time.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: OK. This isn’t working.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You're right. Should we try my back seat? It’s a little bigger -

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: No, Alex. Not this. THIS. He doesn’t get it. JANICE (CONT’D) Us. We’re not working.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? We’re great.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: I know. I know you and I are great. But - where we are - what’s about to happen - that’s not great.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Alex - we're both about to embark on something huge. Separately. And I just think we need to be able to do that - figure out who we are - experience new things. Separately. I just don’t want us to look back 60 years from now and have any regrets. Alex slumps back in his seat, crushed. Silence.  2/18/9 109.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wanted to do this because I thought it would be something that would keep us together.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: But now I see that it’s just something that’s going to hold us back. Alex just looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m really sorry Alex. Alex doesn’t know what to say. He just opens the door and gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Determined, Edison walks into Anarkali carrying the black box. The diners smile back at the little boy. Edison spots Julia at the back table. He approaches, and he nears, Julia turns and sees him -

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Edison? What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: AT THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: Reed enters the restaurant. Takes a few steps in to watch Edison deliver his flowers. But then he sees who Edison i approaching - JULIA. Reed can’t believe his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: WITH EDISON AND JULIA
dialogues.text: As Edison stops in front of Julia, box in hand. Now the whole party is watching. He holds it out to her.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: This is for you.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: For me?

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Are you sure?  2/18/9 110.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Very sure. Julia reluctantly takes the box, not sure what to say. Sh opens it, looks inside, and looks for a good long time at contents before she closes the box and smiles at Edison.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Well, that’s amazingly nice Edison. I’m not sure why you’re doing this, but-

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Because I love you. Julia looks at Edison, heart breaking. She kneels down to his level, looks him in the eye, talks to him quietly.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Listen - I’m sure you’re pretty serious about this - but you don’t really love me. I’m your teacher.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: But I do.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: OK. I don’t think - you just - Julia’s really floundering.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: You're saying I have no shot with you. Julia laughs out loud.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Oh I get that. The age difference alone would be difficult to overcome. I just - I want to give you flowers. I feel like you deserve so much more than you’re getting. This really hits Julia hard. He’s right. As she tries to process this, she sees REED TAKE A FEW MORE STEPS INTO TH RESTAURANT. THEY LOCK EYES.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Honestly, Edison, this is the nicest thing anyone has ever done for me. Sadly, I mean that. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2/18/9 JULIA (cont'd) But I really think you should be giving this to someone else. Edison looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Someone who’s more - appropriate. Someone who can appreciate these more than I can. 111. Julia looks to the back of the restaurant where RANI STAN watching the scene. Edison looks to Rani, then back to Julia.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Rani? But I don’t love her. She's just my friend.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: OK. What makes Rani your friend?

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: I don’t know. She has Tom Waits on her iPod. That’s pretty cool for a fifth grader. Julia smiles, then looks to Reed.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Well, sometimes, those things you like about someone as a friend - they’re the things that turn them into someone you love. Reed looks at Julia, affected by what she’s said. considers this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edison The wide corridor - lined with assistant’s desks - is dar and quiet. Except for one, where Liz sits alone, on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (into phone) Okay. It sounds like we have everyone. I’1l add Erin. One moment. She pushes a few buttons on her phone.  2/18/9 112.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hi, Erin. They’re ready for you. She pushes a few more buttons, stays on the phone for a moment, and then puts the receiver back down, the confere call LIT UP RED on her phone. She stares out the window - until she hears a STRANGE SQUEAKING. She looks a little alarmed - and turns to see Jason, wheeling a cart full of mail down the corridor. She is stunned. She watches him NONCHALANTLY deliver mail empty desks, until arriving at hers.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: (no big deal) Oh. Hey. She’s not sure what to make of him.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Doing a little overtime?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Look, you don’t get ahead in this town without taking a little initiative.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Wait, you’re really here to - But before she can finish her sentence - he pulls a STARB CUP out of his cart.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: White mocha, right? She looks at him, and SMILES WIDE.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Yes. He hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about tonight.  2/18/9 113.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: I just - I like you. And I didn’t know what to do about today - what was too much and what was too little. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: This is perfect. She reaches up and KISSES HIM. A LONG, PASSIONATE KISS.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: So, you have to be here for a while? She points to the phone - where the line is still LIT UP.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Until they’re done with the call. You want to hang out with me?

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Yeah. He sits on the floor of her cubby, back against her filin drawers. She grabs her mocha and sits next to him.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I like you too. Jason beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reed watches as Edison stands across from Rani at the fro of the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: I’m really sorry about what those girls did to you today.

dialogues.speaker: RANI
dialogues.text: That’s OK. They’re not that smart.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: They're not, right? Edison stands there awkwardly, holding the black box.  2/18/9 114.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Well anyway, here. He hands her the bouquet. She takes the box, opens it. Pulls out the SINGLE FLOWER. It’s a RARE THAI PARROT FLOW Deep, vibrant purple, like no other flower you’ve ever se And amazingly shaped like a PARROT. It’s stunning. Rani can’t believe her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: I don’t usually go for girls my age, but you’re pretty sophisticated.

dialogues.speaker: RANI
dialogues.text: Thank you. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: I don’t really have anything else to say.

dialogues.speaker: RANI
dialogues.text: Me either. Rani smiles at Edison. He smiles back. WITH REED - as he approaches Julia at the other side of t restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: So. You're here.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Yep. Back at the Valentine’s Day singles dinner. A loser once again. (off the reaction of the other party guests) Sorry guys. Reed takes her arm, gently guides her a bit away.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: You are not a loser. You just - deserve better. Julia smiles, a bit taken aback by the compliment.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: So why didn’t you go?  2/18/9 115.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Honestly? Because somewhere, deep inside, I did know. I knew that it wasn’t right. But I also knew that you were getting married, and that what you and I had, our friendship as we knew it, was going to end. So I just blinded myself to all the signs. Because I didn’t want to be left with nothing. Reed looks at her, a small smile crosses his face. He tak one imperceptible step towards her.

dialogues.speaker: REED
dialogues.text: And now that I have nothing? Julia stands her ground, matches his smile.

dialogues.speaker: JULIA
dialogues.text: Then I guess we can both have nothing. Together. Reed now breaks out into a wide grin. Julia does too, she can’t help herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music cue: This Will Be Our Year - The Zombies

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelvin sits behind the news desk, doing his 10 o’clock report.

dialogues.speaker: KELVIN
dialogues.text: I'd like to take a moment and comment on the story we reported earlier - Sean Jackson's coming out. A ground-breaking day in sports, for sure - Mr. Jackson's name likely to be remembered along side the likes of Jackie Robinson, Muhammad Ali, Billie Jean King. But let’s let future generations decide where to place this. Today, of all days, I would like to look at this act not as one of defiance, or wall-busting, or history making - but simply as this: what a man will do for love. Off camera - Susan watches, pleased. And standing a few f away from her - KARA, beaming ear to ear.  2/18/9 116. INT. EDGAR & ESTELLE’S HOUSE - DOORWAY/HALLWAY - NIGHT Darkness. A FIGURE uses a key, enters the home, walking softly inside the sleeping household. The FIGURE quietly makes its way down the hallway towards back of the house. Reaches a closed door. Pushes it open. INT. EDGAR & ESTELLE’S HOUSE - EDISON’S ROOM - NIGHT Posters of the Space Shuttle and the Solar System on the walls. Edison is sound asleep. His hair covers his face. A HAND touches him gently. Edison slowly stirs. The Hand shakes him a bit harder this time. Until he opens his eye SHOCK on his face. Not believing what he’s seeing. He reaches over and turns on a lamp, shaped like a rocket sh The Figure is: KATE. Still in her soldier uniform.

dialogues.speaker: EDISON
dialogues.text: Mommy! You’re here! She pulls him into her arms. Breathing in his scent. Kissing his eyes, his face, his ears. Anything she can.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE DOORWAY
dialogues.text: Stands Edgar and Estelle, in their pajamas, holding hands They silently watch the reunion of their daughter and the grandson. Then quietly turn and give them space. INT. JANICE’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT Janice sits up in her bed, which is still surrounded by t candles Alex brought. They are all lit. She’s paging through the YALE COURSE CATALOG. Her PHONE BUZZES. She picks it up - there’s a NEW TEXT

dialogues.speaker: MESSAGE FROM ALEX
dialogues.text: I’l1l always love you. She smiles, closes her phone. Curls up in bed. INT. ALPHONSO’S HOUSE - NIGHT Alphonso and his WIFE are dead asleep, buffered by their - ALPHONSO JR. (6) AND CARMEN (4) who sleep between them.  2/18/9 117.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason and Liz drive down Beverly, BOTH ON HIS VESPA. As h weaves in and out of traffic, she holds on for dear life, laughing the whole time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean sits on the deck, watching the moon reflect off the ocean. He seems relaxed, at peace. He hears the sliding door from his house open, turns to s HOLDEN - standing there with his bags. Sean can’t believe his eyes. He rushes to him and hugs him - holds him tight They both tear up.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: You saw? Holden nods, still hugging Sean.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: This isn’t going to be easy.

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: I don’t care. Holden looks at Sean, taking him in.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDEN
dialogues.text: So what next?

dialogues.speaker: SEAN
dialogues.text: How do you feel about Buffalo? Holden smiles, follows Sean back in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From outside, we can see into the lit up cafe side of the store. It’s empty except for one table - Reed and Julia s across from each other, talking. As they laugh, completely at ease with each other, the ca moves up, looking down 6th street, downtown LA coming int view. We then tilt up to the night sky, stopping at the bright white moon, which looks like a heart. Not really. It just looks like the moon. The end.
